(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
1
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr.
Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce that the October 1978 Term of the
Supreme Court of the United States is now convened."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–1036. Jean D. Larsen, etc., appellant, v. Raphael Lock-
hart. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Motion of appellee for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–1340. Harold Smith, appellant, v. Rosita Gummo et al.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District. The appeal is dismised for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Stevens
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 77-1373. Maine Central Railroad Company, appellant, v.
Raymond L. Halperin et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court
of Maine. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice.
Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 77-1568. Missouri Church of Scientology, appellant, v. State
Tax Commission of Missouri et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and
set the case for oral argument.
280-278-78-1

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
No. 77-1570. William Craig Millis et al., appellants, v. High
Drive Water District et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Colorado. Judgment affirmed.
No. 78–199. Mortgage Growth Investors, appellant, v. Clow Cor-
poration et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Michigan. Judgment affirmed.
No. 77-1584. Association of Personnel Agencies of New York,
Inc., et al., appellants, v. Philip Ross, as Industrial Commissioner of
the State of New York, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 77-1723. Aristocratic Restaurant of Massachusetts, Inc., ap-
pellant, v. Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission; Aristocratic "
Restaurant of Massachusetts, Inc., appellant, v. Alcoholic Beverages
Control Commission. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of,
Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 77–1737. Roloff Evangelistic Enterprises, Inc., et al. appel-
lants, v. Texas. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas,
Third Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1743. Downtown L.A. Imports et al., appellants. v. Su-
perior Court of California, County of Los Angeles (Evelle J. Younger,
Attorney General of California, Real Party in Interest). Appeal from
the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-1775. Rentar Industrial Development Corp., et al., appel-
lants, v. Carl A. Morse, Inc., etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeals
of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question.
No. 77–1834. John H. Lang, appellant, v. City of Philadelphia
et al. Appeal from the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77-6713. Ann Keyes, appellant, v. Oklahoma Department
of Institutions, Social and Rehabilitative Services, et al. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Oklahoma. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-28. Barbara J. Sanko et al., appellants, v. Jan E. Carlson,
etc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
3
No. 78-39. Joseph A. Zrenchik et al., appellants, v. Peoples' Com-
munity Hospital Authority. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
Michigan. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 78-57. Five-R Excavating, Inc., appellant, v. Pennsylvania
Department of Revenue; J & R Equipment Rental Company, Inc., v.
Pennsylvania Departmentof Revenue. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Pennsylvania, Western District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-73. John Wright et al., appellants, v. City of Indianapolis
et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Indiana. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-101. Betty J. Roberts, appellant, v. Robert D. Roberts.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-104. James Johnson et al., appellants, v. Attorney General
of Maryland, et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Maryland.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–138. Westinghouse Electric Corporation, appellant, v.
Pennsylvania. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Western District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 78-5001. Thomas Francis, appellant, v. Massachusetts; David
O'Clair, appellant, v. Massachusetts. Appeal from the Supreme Judi-
cial Court of Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 78-5081. Betty (Minyard) Stein, appellant, v. Texas Power
and Light Company and William Andress, Jr. Appeal from the Court
of Civil Appeals of Texas, Second Supreme Judicial District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 77–1592. Bobby C. Cambron, et al., appellants, v. Canal In-
surance Company. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 77-1631. James L. Ridgill, et ux., appellants, v. Reston Home-
owners Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
No. 77-1642. Mark Cheramie et al., appellants, v. Numa Guidry
et ux. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-1726. Herman Appleman, appellant, v. Erick Furedy, etc.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–1825. Sarah A. Arthur et al., appellants, v. Clay Commu-
nity Schools et al.; Roy Tolin et al., appellants, v. Southwest Parke
Community School Corporation et al. Appeal from the Court of Ap-
peals of Indiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-1854. Charles E. Sigety et al., appellants, v. Charles J.
Hynes, etc., et al. Appeal from the Appellate Division, Supreme
Court of New York, First Judicial Department. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 77-6671. Dominick Saffioti, appellant, v. New York. Appeal
from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 77-6745. William E. Conrad, appellant, v. First State Bank
& Trust Co., etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6837. William E. Conrad, appellant, v. H. Kenneth Wan-
gelin et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6900. William F. Mackey, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.

No. 77-6914. Keith B. Davis, appellant, v. Lawyers Professional
Responsibility Board of Minnesota, et al. Appeal from the Supreme

Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-6988. Martin L. Bloch and Marilyn Bloch, appellants, v.
General Motors Acceptance Corporation. Appeal from the Appellate
Division, Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial Dept. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 77–6999. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Essex County Bank
& Trust Company. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77–7003. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Essex County News-
papers, Inc. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-74. Ralph Wayne Theis, appellant, v. City of San Antonio,
etc. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Twelfth
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5091. Rodney Kelley, appellant, v. Robert E. Johnson and
Joan Johnson. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vermont. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-5092. Thomas Alexander, Jr., appellant v. Delaware State
Bar Association. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Delaware. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-5117. Kenneth Hemmerle, et ux., and James C. Dean, et
ux., appellants v. T. J. McDowell. Appeal from the District Court of
Appeal of Florida, Second District. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
No. 78-5131. In the Matter of James Wallis Morris, appellant.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of South Carolina. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5185. Maxine M. Jenkins, appellant, v. District of Colum-
bia. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 77-1621. Byron Timothy Liggett, appellant, v. Kansas, ex rel.
Curt T. Schneider, Attorney General of the State of Kansas, et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Kansas. Motion of American
Physicians and Surgeons, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 77-1670. Suffolk Outdoor Advertising Co., Inc., appellant, v.
Theodore O. Hulse et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal ques-
tion. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell would note prob-
able jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 77-1671. Modjeska Sign Studios, Inc., appellant, v. Peter
A. A. Berle, etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell would note probable juris-
diction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 77–1784. Veterans of Foreign Wars, Post 4264, et al., appel-
lants, v. City of Steamboat Springs. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice
Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 77–6604. Charles Little, appellant, v. Nebraska. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Nebraska. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
White would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 77-6635. Kelly Weeks, Sr., appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal from
the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan▸
and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set
the case for oral argument.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
7
No. 77-6749. Colson Carter, appellant, v. C. Leslie Dawson, Sec-
retary, Department for Human Resources, Kentucky. Appeal from
the Court of Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question. Quern v. Mandley, 436 U.S.
(1978).
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-792. Bernard G. Rubin, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the So-
licitor General in his supplemental brief filed August 21, 1978. Mr.
Justice Rehnquist dissents.
No. 77-1599. Georgiena N. Cook, petitioner, v. Muskingum
Watershed Conservancy District. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition
for a writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Monell v.
Department of Social Services of New York City, 436 U.S.
(1978).
No. 77-1663. Society for the Welfare of Animals, Inc., petitioner,
v. David B. Walrath. On petition for writ of certiorari to the District
Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District. Motion of Humane So-
ciety of the United States for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third
District, for further consideration in light of Bates v. State Bar of
Arizona, 433 U.S. 350 (1977).
No. 77-6536. John Cornelius Hammons, petitioner, v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of the position presently asserted by
the Solicitor General in his memorandum filed July 11, 1978. The
Chief Justice, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissent.
No. 77-6910. Benson Joseph Donoho, petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further

8
MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978
consideration in light of the position presently asserted by the Solicitor
General in his memorandum filed September 5, 1978. Mr. Justice
Rehnquist dissents.
No. 77–6912. Edgar Gilbert Miller, petitioner, v. Kentucky. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari are granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for further considera-
tion in light of Taylor v. Kentucky, 436 U.S. - (1978).
No. 77-6992. Ronald Paul Bishop, petitioner, v. Arizona. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undis-
turbed the death penalty imposed, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Arizona for further proceedings. See Lockett v. Ohio, 438
U.S.
-
(1978).
No. 77–7002. Eugene L. Adams, petitioner, v. Ohio. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undisturbed
the death penalty imposed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Ohio for further proceedings. See Lockett v. Ohio, 438 U.S. ·
(1978).
No. 78-44. Paul A. Pemberton, petitioner, v. Lawrence Sperandio.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further consideration
in light of Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 436 U.S.
(1978).
No. 78–87. Environmental Defense Fund, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. East Bay Municipal Utility District et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of California for further consideration in light of
California v. United States, 438 U.S. ——— (1978).
No. 78–5008. William V. Nabozny, petitioner, v. Ohio. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari are granted. Judgment vacated insofar as it leaves undis-
turbed the death penalty imposed, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Ohio for further proceedings. See Lockett v Ohio, 438
U.S. (1978).

Children's Services, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District, denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant
certiorari.
No. 77-1710. National Wildlife Art Exchange, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, v. Franklin Mint Corporation. Motion of Ambassador Graphic
Arts, Inc., et al. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 77–1780. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. United States Tobacco
Company. Motion of Multitsate Tax Commission for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District, denied. Mr. Justice
White would grant certiorari.
No. 77–1785. Kerr-McGee Chemical Corporation, petitioner, v.
Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell would grant certiorari.
No. 77-1790. Clive J. Davis, petitioner, v. Joint Bar Association
Grievance Committee for the Second and Eleventh Judicial Districts.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division of the Su-
preme Court of New York, Second Judicial Department, denied. Mr.
Justice Marshall would grant certorari.
No. 77-1809. Sedalia-Marshall-Boonville Stage Line, Inc., peti-
tioner, v. National Mediation Board et al. Motion of Commuter Air-
line Association of America for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Motion of Airline Industrial Relations Conference et al. for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. Petition for writ of certi-
orari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
denied.
No. 77-1826. Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. Consumer Product Safety Commission et al. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

No. 77–6702. William "Bill" Campbell, petitioner, v. Georgia;

MONDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1978

No. 77–6563. Irvin Paul Dunsdon, petitioner, v. Utah;

No. 77–6691. Levis Leon Aldridge, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida;
No. 77-6774. Dewayne Hulsey, petitioner, v. Arkansas. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas denied; and
denied
No. 77–6809. Wesley H. Peery, petitioner, v. Nebraska. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our views
that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual pun-
ishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg
v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certiorari
and vacate the death sentences in these cases.
No. 77-6484. Charles L. Baker, Sr., petitioner, v. Georgia. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6607. Larry Johnson, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan would grant certiorari.
No. 77-6953. Richard Schmidt, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan would grant certiorari.

ORAL ARGUMENTS
No. 77-388. Washington et al., appellants, v. Confederated Bands
and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation. Argued by Mr. Slade
Gorton for the appellants, by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the United
States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. James
B. Hovis for the appellees.
No. 77–719. Jerome D. Chapman, Commissioner of Texas Depart-
ment of Human Resources, et al., petitioners, v. Houston Welfare
Rights Organization et al. Argued by Mr. David H. Young for the
petitioners and by Mr. Jeffrey J. Skarda for the respondents.
No. 77-5324. Julia Gonzalez, etc., petitioner, v. James F. Young,
Director, Hudson County Welfare Board, et al. Argued by Mr. Theo-
dore A. Gardner for the petitioner and by M. Stephen Skillman for
the respondents.
No. 77-120. Dougherty County, Georgia Board of Education, et
al., appellants, v. John E. White. Argument commenced by Mr. Jesse
W. Walters for the appellants.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1978
135
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 78–540. New York Times Company and Myron Farber,
petitioners, . New Jersey and Mario E. Jascalevich. Motion to vacate
stay granted, and it is ordered that the order of Mr. Justice Stewart
dated September 26, 1978, is hereby, vacated. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
☑
280-278-78-12

}

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1978
137
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1711. Patrick Francis Simpson, appellant, v. Georgia.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would reverse the conviction.
No. 77-1849. Chicago Sheraton Corporation, appellant, v. Seymour
Zaban et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Illinois. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction
and set the case for oral argument.
No. 78–236. Metropolitan Development and Housing Agency,
appellant, v. South Central Bell Telephone Company et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-5267. Lennie Mae White, appellant, v. James C. Stubbs.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-5296. Ella Hornick, appellant, v. Young Women's
Christian Association of Madison, Wisconsin, Inc. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 78–246. W. B. Armstrong, appellant, v. New Mexico. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of New Mexico. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.

thority of Beaver County, Beaver, Pennsylvania, et al. Appeal from

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1978
the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsyl-

No. 78–276. Roland Lerner, appellant, v. Charles J. Hynes, Deputy
Attorney General of the State of New York; Far Rockaway Nursing

of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. The appeal as to
Far Rockaway Nursing Home et al. dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 77-654. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, Inc., petitioner,
v. Federal Trade Commission. Motion of Samuel E. Parker et al, for
leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, denied. Motion of Small Business
Legislative Council for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions.

al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

additional minutes for oral argument. Motion of Solicitor General for

No. 78-5159. Carzell Moore, petitioner, v. Georgia. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering to our views
that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual pun-
ishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, Gregg

148
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1978
v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant certiorari
and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 78-5240. Anderson Hughes, petitioner, v. Texas. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering
to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, October 16, 1978, until

of Department of Human Resources, et al., appellants, v. J. L. and

et al. One and one-half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by

Louis F. Claiborne for the United States.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1978
157
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 77-1515. The Long Island Rail Road Company, petitioner, v.
Aberdeen & Rockfish Railroad Company et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ffth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted limited to question 1 presented
by the petition. Judgment reversed insofar as it requires petitioner to
keep the proceeds collected from its interim terminal surcharge in a
separate trust, and remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
per curiam.
No. 78–229. Bernard Carey, State's Attorney of Cook County,
Illinois, appellant, v. Ralph M. Wynn et al.; and
No. 78–239. Eugene F. Diamond, appellant, v. Ralph M. Wynn
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois. Appeals dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these cases.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-6835. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Town of Ipswich.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for a writ of certiorari,
motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for a writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of Monell v. De-
partment of Social Services of New York City, 436 U.S. (1978).
-
No. 77-6868. Donald Gene Runyan, appellant, v. California.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a final judgment.
280-278-78-16

158
MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1978
No. 78–265. James W. Willman, appellant, v. Minnesota. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–278. Estaban Torres, Conservator of the Estate of Amalia
Torres, Appellant v. Illinois. Appeal from the Appellate Court of Illi-
nois, Third District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5255. Rodney J. Kelley, appellant, v. Vermont. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed for want.
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–294. Southern California Edison Company, appellant, v.
Public Utilities Commission of California. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a properly
presented federal question.

from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1978
167
No. 77-1687. Jacob James Dost, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 78-5007. Thomas Edward Kilfoyle, petitioner, v. United
States. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari and reverse.
the convictions.
No. 77-1736. Albert Smith, President of the Village of Skokie,
Illinois, et al., petitioners, v. Frank Collin et al. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom
Mr. Justice White joins.
denied
No. 77-7009. Darrell Edwin Hoy, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall, dissenting: Adhering
to our views that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and
unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amend-
ments, Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 227, 231 (1976), we would grant
certiorari and vacate the death sentence in this case.
No. 78-289. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, petitioner, c.
First Empire Bank-New York et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Blackmun would grant certiorari.
No. 78-5213. Temo Rodriguez, petitioner, v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 78-5407. Clovis Carl Green, Jr., petitioner, v. Missouri Board
of Probation and Parole. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of
habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITIONS FOR WRITS OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 78-5351. Clovis Carl Green, Jr., petitioner, v. Richard Ral-
ston, United States Magistrate, et al.; and
No. 78-5368. Benjamin Franklin Vick, petitioner, v. United
States. Motions for leave to file petitions for writs of mandamus denied.

☑



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1978
175
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78–80. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Baylor
University Medical Center. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Cir-
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of
Beth Israel Hospital v. NLRB, 437 U.S. · (1978), only on the cafe-
teria issue. Insofar as the petition seeks review of the corridor issue,
petition denied. Opinion per curiam. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
-
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-55. Broadway Books, Inc., appellant, v. Virginia et al.
Appeal from the Circuit Court of the City of Richmond, Division I.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Stewart would dismiss for want of a properly presented fed-
eral question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall would
reverse judgment.
No. 78-64. New York, appellant, v. United States. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
No. 78–259. Boston Edison Company, appellant, v. Department
of Public Utilities of Massachusetts et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Judicial Court of Massachusetts. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereupon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5342. Maxine M. Jenkins, appellant, v. The Evening Star
Newspaper Company et al. Appeal from the United States Court of
280-278-78-17

176
MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1978
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5380. Kenneth Hemmerle et al., appellants, v. First Fed-
eral Savings and Loan Association of DeSoto County, etc. Appeal
from the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certi-
orari denied.
No. 78-293. Avery Federal Savings and Loan Association et al.,
appellants, v. William D. Meyers et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of Kentucky. The appeal is dismissed for want of a final
judgment. (See 28 U.S.C. § 1257)
No. 78-359. William J. Hord et al., appellants, v. Reubin Askew,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-372. Lawrence Moskowitz et al., appellants, v. Charles J.
Hynes, etc. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–376. Fred Pabst, Jr., appellant, v. Vermont Commissioner
of Taxes. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–377. Gilbert D. Scudder, appellant, v. Florida Power
Corporation et al. Appeal from the District Court of Appeal of Flor-
ida, Second District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
No. 78–386. City of Rochester and Thomas R. Frey, appellants,
v. Jeannette C. Waldert. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 78-389. Leslie Kaye et al., appellants, v. Robert P. Whalen,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-40. Western Oil & Gas Association et al., petitioners, v.
Alaska et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Petition for a
writ of certiorari is granted. Part II-C of decision below vacated and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia for dismissal of paragraph 37 (j) of the complaint.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1978
177
No. 78-327. California, petitioner, v. Jesse W., a Minor. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed informa pauperis granted. Peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is granted, judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further considera-
tion in light of Swisher v. Brady, 438 U.S. (1978).
-
ORDER IN PENDING CASES
No. A-285. Kenneth Wayne applicant, v. Oklahoma. Ap-
plication for bail, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him re-
ferred to the Court, denied.
No. A-305. International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation,
applicant, v. Securities and Exchange Commission. Application for
stay, presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court,
denied.
No. 77–1248. Illinois State Board of Elections, appellant, v. So-
cialist Workers Party et al. Motion of Socialist Workers Party for
divided argument granted.
No. 77-1258. Minnesota, petitioner, v. First of Omaha Service
Corporation et al.; and
No. 77-1265. Marquette National Bank of Minneapolis, peti-
tioner, v. First of Omaha Service Corporation et al. Motion of peti-
tioners for divided argument granted.
No. 77–1493. Gladstone Realtors et al., petitioners, v. Village of
Bellwood et al. Motion of Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amicus curiae,granted and fifteen additional min-
utes allotted for that purpose. Petitioners allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.
No. 77–1547. Douglas Oil Company of California et al., peti-
tioners, v. Petrol Stops Northwest et al. Motion of Solicitor General
for divided argument granted.
No. 77-1578. Broadcast Music, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Colum-
bia Broadcasting System, Inc., et al.; and
No. 77-1583. American Society of Composers, Authors and Pub-
lishers, et al., petitioners, v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., et
al. Motion of CBS, Inc., for additional time for oral argument granted.
and fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. Peti-
tioners allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 77-6217. Edward Ray Stacy, etc., appellant, v. Florida. Ap-
pellee invited to file response to petition for rehearing within thirty
days.

178
MONDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1978
No. 77-6431. Abdiel Caban, appellant, v. Kazim Mohammed and
Maria Mohammed. Order heretofore entered on October 10, 1978, va-
cated and brief, amicus curiae, of Legal Aid Society of New York City
ordered filed.
No. 78-201. John B. Greenholtz, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Inmates
of the Nebraska Penal and Correctional Complex et al. Motion of re-
spondents for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that
Brian K. Ridenour, Esquire, of Lincoln, Nebraska, is appointed to
serve as counsel in this case.
No. 78–657. Isabel Kimble et al., appellants, v. William D. Swack- |
hamer, Secretary of State of Nevada, et al. Application for an injunc-
tion, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court, denied.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 78-6. Hilmar G. Moore et al., appellants, v. John Pleasant
Sims et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Texas. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 78–329. Francis X. Bellotti, Attorney General of Massachu-
setts, et al., appellants, v. William Baird et al.; and
No. 78-330. Jane Hunerwadel, etc., appellant, v. William Baird
et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the District
of Massachusetts. In these cases probable jurisdiction noted. Cases
consolidated and a total of one hour allotted for oral argument.
No. 78–357. Robert R. Williams et al., appellants, v. Leila G.
Brown et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction noted. Case set for
oral argument in tandem with City of Mobile v. Bolden, No. 77–1844.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 78-58. G. Garvin Brown, III, petitioner, v. Mark Paul Felsen.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit granted.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1978
207
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr.
Justice Stevens.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-417. Quentin Rogers et al., applicants, v. Herman Lodge
et al. Application for stay of order of the United States District
Court for the Southern District of Georgia, presented to Mr. Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court, granted pending final dis-
position of the appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit.
No. 78–710. Allen Klein, petitioner, v. United States. Application
for stay, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to
the Court, denied.

280-278-78--21



1
(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1978
209
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77–6885. Virgil Delano Presnell, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia.
Petition for writ of certiorafi as to the conviction for kidnapping
for. leave. proceed in forma pasiperis and.
bodily injury and the imposition of the death sentence granted. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Insofar as the petition challenges the convictions for murder, kidnap-
ping and statutory rape, petition denied. Opinion per curiam. Concur-
ring statement by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring statement by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom
the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–123. Willie C. Acker, appellant, v. Board of Trustees of
Pass Christian Municipal Separate School District. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Mississippi. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 78–446. William T. Dunham et ux., appellants, v. Clackamas
: County. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Oregon. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–465. Frank D. Napolitano et ux., appellants, v. Wyoming
State Highway Department and State Highway Commission. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Wyoming. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–297. Manchester News Company, Inc., appellant, v. New
Hampshire. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Hampshire. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a final judgment. See 28 U.S.C. 1257.
No. 78-381. Clarence H. Holding, appellant, v. BVA Crediţ
Corporation. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal
280-278-78-22

210
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1978
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
No. 78–397. Susan Garfinkle et vir, appellants, v. Superior Court
of Contra Costa County (Wells Fargo Bank et al., Real Parties in
Interest). Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–6817. Maurice McElwee, petitioner, v. Texas. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further
consideration in light of Crist v. Bretz, 437 U.S.—(1978).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-376. Frederick B. Pfister, applicant, v. Anderson Clinic,
Inc., et al. Application for stay of orders of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall
and referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-73. In the Matter of Disbarment of John J. McGovern. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-102. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter Victor Pappas.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-117. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert A. Eisenberg.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-131. In the Matter of Disbarment of Truman Kella Gibson,
Jr. Disbarment entered.
No. D-133. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gene Loy Chu. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-143. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alton S. Beasley. It
is ordered that Alton S. Beasley, of Okeechobee, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 77-1410. William E. Butner, petitioner, v. United States et al.
Motion of Solicitor General for divided argument granted.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1978
229
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 77–1792. Board of Trustees of Keene State College et al.,
petitioners, v. Christine M. Sweeney. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for reconsideration in light of Furnco Con-
struction Co. v. Waters, 438 U.S.-(1978). Opinion per curiam.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-431. Sherman M. Godsy, Jr., appellant, v. Nadine Godsy.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kansas City District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certi-
orari denied.
No. 78-5458. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Town of Topsfield.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 78-5507. David Eugene Harto, appellant, v. Colorado. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-467. Enntex Oil & Gas Company (of Nevada) et al., ap-
pellants, v. Texas. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas,
Sixth Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
280-278-78-25

230
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1978
No. 78-5329. Carlos O. D. Henry, appellant, v. Colorado. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Colorado. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Stevens would
note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-364. Joseph A. Schafer et al., applicants, v. Penn Central
Transportation Company et al. Application for stay, addressed to the
Chief Justice and referred to the Court denied.
No. 76–419. Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation, peti-
tioner, v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc. et al.; and
No. 76-528. Consumers Power Company, petitioner, v. Nelson
Aeschliman et al. Motions of respondents for elimination or reduction
of taxed costs denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 77-983. Washington et al., petitioners, v. Washington State
Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Association et al.; Washington
et al., petitioners, v. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al.;
No. 78–119. Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et
al.; and
No. 78–139. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al., petition-
ers, v. United States District Court for the Western District of Wash-
ington (United States et al., Real Parties in Interest). Motion of
Solicitor General and motion of respondent Indian Tribes (except the
Yakima Indian Nation) to consolidate these cases for the purpose of
briefing and argument granted. Briefing schedule of Solicitor General
as set out in his motion is adopted by the Court. Total time of two
hours heretofore granted by the Court in these cases is reduced to one
and one half hours and divided as follows: 30 minutes to the Solicitor
General; 30 minutes to the State of Washington; 15 minutes to the
Indian Tribe and 15 minutes to the association of non-Indian fisher-
men.
No. 78-729. Arrow Food Distributors, Inc., petitioner, v. Lloyd
F. Love, Conservator of the Estate of William F. Riley, Jr. Applica-
tion for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and referred to the
Court, denied.
No. 78-761. American Telephone and Telegraph Company et al.,
petitioners, v. United States. That portion of the order entered by the
Chief Justice on November 2, 1978, which stayed the order of the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit,
entered October 31, 1978, pending filing of response vacated and
application denied.

No. 77-1863. J. P. Mitchell, Warden, petitioner, v. Raymond
Bradley Nottingham, Jr. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 78–180. William D. Leeke, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Walter
Gordon; George H. Collins, Warden, petitioner, v. Wayne Stephen
Young. Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1978
No. 78-182. O. E. Serwold et ux., petitioners, v. Kenneth N. Nelson.
Motion of Stephen W. Holohan for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 78–317. DuPont Glore Forgan Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
American Telephone & Telegraph Company et al. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this petition.
No. 78-5177. Floyd Harris, petitioner, v. Oklahoma. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma
denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr.
Justice Marshall joins.
No. 78-5489. Preston Hall, petitioner, v. California. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appel-
late District, denied. Mr. Justice White would grant certiorari.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 78-464. Curtin Matheson Scientific, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
C. M. Russell, Jr., et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of
certiorari and/or petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1978
249
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-553. Automotive Service Councils of Michigan et al., ap-
pellants, v. Richard H. Austin, Secretary of State for the State of
Michigan. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Michigan. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-5486. Leonard Ridzon, appellant, v. Janet Mollenkopf,
Director of the Board of Elections of Columbiana County, Ohio. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Ohio. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
No. 78-5560. Roy Charles Bell, Sr., appellant, v. Ruby Carpio
Bell et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari is denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-2. Illinois, petitioner, v. John M. Vitale. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. The petition for
a writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Illinois to consider whether its judgment is
based upon federal or state constitutional grounds, or both. See Cali-
fornia v. Krivda, 409 U.S. 33 (1972). Mr. Justice White and Mr. Jus-
tice Blackmun would grant certiorari and set case for oral argument.
No. 78–370. City of West Haven, petitioner, v. Thomas Turpin.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed.
in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
280-278-78-27

250
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1978
Monell v. Department of Social Services of New York City, 436 U.S.
658 (1978).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-437. Winthrop Drake Thies, applicant v. Joint Bar Asso-
ciation Grievance Committee. Application for stay, addressed to Mr.
Justice Powell and referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-135. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Henry Kutza.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-144. In the Matter of Disbarment of Burton G. Hirsch. It is
ordered that Burton G. Hirsch of Phoenix, Arizona, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-145. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald J. Shaker. It is
ordered that Donald J. Shaker, of Pittsfield, Massachusetts, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-146. In the Matter of Disbarment of Myron Teitelbaum. It is
ordered that Myron Teitelbaum, of Dayton, Ohio, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–147. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard F. Pence. It is
ordered that Richard F. Pence, of Parkersburg, West Virginia, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-148. In the Matter of Disbarment of Maurice Curran Clem,
Jr. It is ordered that Maurice Curran Clem, Jr., of Henderson, Ken-
tucky, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 5, Original. United States, plaintiff, v. State of California. On
motion for entry of a third supplemental decree. Third supplemental
decree entered and ordered filed. The Court retains jurisdiction to
entertain such further proceedings. enter such orders, and issue such
writs as from time to time may be deemed necessary or advisable to give
proper force and effect to this decree and the prior decrees of this
Court or to effectuate the rights of the parties in the premises. Mr.
Justice Marshall took no part in the formulation of this decree.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1978
251
No. 80, Original. State of Colorado, plaintiff, v. State of New
Mexico and Toney Anaya, Attorney General of New Mexico. Motion
for leave to file bill of complaint granted and defendants allowed
sixty days in which to answer.
No. 76-1471. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, v.
National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.;
No. 76–1521. Channel Two Television Company et al., petitioners,
v. National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.;
No. 76-1595. National Association of Broadcasters, petitioner, v.
Federal Communications Commission et al.;
No. 76-1604. American Newspaper Publishers Association, peti-
tioner . National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.;
No. 76–1624. Illinois Broadcasting Company, Inc., et al., peti-
tioners, . National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting et al.; and
No. 76-1685. Post Company et al., petitioners, v. National Citizens
Committee for Broadcasting et al. Motion of National Citizens Com-
mittee for Broadcasting to waive or retax costs denied. Mr. Justice.
Brennan took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

al. Motion of Solicitor General for additional time to present oral argu-
ment on behalf of the United States, as amicus curiae, denied. The time
allotted for oral argument is divided as follows: 30 minutes to peti-
tioners; 15 minutes to Solicitor General, as amicus curiae; 45 minutes
to respondents.

OPINIONS
No. 77-515. Holt Civic Club, etc., et al., appellants, v. City of Tus-
caloosa, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Alabama. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White
and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77-120. Dougherty County, Georgia Board of Education, et
al., appellants, v. John E. White. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Middle District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join and joined in
Part I by Mr. Justice Stewart.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77-5992. Frank O'Neal Addington, appellant, v. Texas.
Argued by Miss Martha L. Boston for the appellant, by Mr. James F.
Hury, Jr. for the appellee, and by Mr. Joel I. Klein for the American
Psychiatric Association, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.

Rasmussen et al.; and

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1978
281
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmum, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78–344. Union Pacific Railroad Co., petitioner, v. Kermit Kim-
ball Sheehan. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave
to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice.
Marshall concur in the result.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-70. Wilkes County, Georgia et al., appellants, v. United
States; Wilkes County School District et al., appellants, v. United
States. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 78-439. Bridgeport Hydraulic Company et al., appellants, v.
Council on Water Company Lands of Connecticut et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut. Judg-
ment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would
vacate judgment and remand case to the United States District Court
for the District of Connecticut for further consideration in light of
Penn Central Transportation Company v. City of New York, 438
U.S.
(1978).
No. 78-574. Gibson Distributing Company, Inc., et al., appellants,
v. Downtown Development Association of El Paso, Inc. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Notice of appeal was not filed within the time provided
by 28 U.S.C. 2101 (c).
280-278-78-
31

282
MONDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1978
No. 78-5258. Fannie Perillo, appellant, v. Pennsylvania Depart-
ment of Public Welfare. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Penn-
sylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Stevens
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 78-5408. Anna Selma Vinje Morpurgo, appellant, v. Profes-
sional Staff Congress/CUNY et al. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.

OPINIONS
No. 77-5781. Frank L. Rakas and Lonnie L. King, petitioners, v.
Illinois. On writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Third
District. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 77–837. New Motor Vehicle Board of the State of California
et al., appellants, v. Orrin W. Fox Co. et al.; and
No. 77–849. Northern California Motor Car Dealers Association
et al., appellants, v. Orrin W. Fox Co., et al. Appeals from the United
States District Court for the Central District of California. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
Central District of California for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun concurring in the result with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1978
299
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-602. Tuscan Dairy Farms, Inc., appellant, v. J. Roger
Barber, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets of New York. Ap-
peal from the Court of Appeals of New York. Motion of the Great
Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question. Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens would note
probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 78-608. Cassandra Lumpkin, appellant v. Department of So-
cial Services of New York et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 78-657. Isabel Kimble et al., appellants, v. William D. Swack-
hamer, Secretary of State of Nevada, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Nevada. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 78-646. Southern California Edison Company, appellant, v.
Public Utilities Commission of the State of California et al. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of California. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr.
Justice Powell would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for
oral argument.
No. 78-663. Borough of Fox Chapel et al., appellants, v. John A.
Friday. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western
District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5587. David Ballentine, appellant, v. Walter Fogg, Su-
perintendent, Green Haven Correctional Facility. Appeal from the
280-278-78-34

300
MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1978
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The appeal is
dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-477. Joseph Hopper, Warden, petitioner, v. Tyrone F.
Barnett. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals with
directions to dismiss the cause as moot.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-147. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard F. Pence.
The Rule to show cause discharged and order entered November 27,
1978, vacated.
No. D-149. In the Matter of Disbarment of Albert J. Genua, Jr.
It is ordered that Albert J. Genua, Jr., of Rocky Hill, Connecticut, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-150. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack F. C. Gillard.
It is ordered that Jack F. C. Gillard, of Albert Lea, Minnesota, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he |
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-151. In the Matter of Disbarment of Charles E. Hopfl. It |
is ordered that Charles E. Hopfl, of New York, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-152. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael F. Waters.
It is ordered that Michael F. Waters, of Brooklyn, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, 1
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-153. In the Matter of Disbarment of J. Jerome Olitt. It is
ordered that J. Jerome Olitt, of White Plains, New York, be sus- E
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

OPINIONS
No. 77-1115. Robert M. Lalli, appellant, v. Rosamond Lalli, Ad-
ministratrix of the Estate of Mario Lalli. Appeal from the Court of
Appeals of New York. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Powell an-
nounced judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Stewart joined. Concurring opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun con-
curring in the judgment. Statement by Mr. Justice Rehnquist concur-
ring the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with
whom Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens
join.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1978
315
No. 77-832. Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System,
petitioner v. First Lincolnwood Corporation. On writ of certiorari to
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 77-1016. United California Bank and Lillian Disney Tru-
yens, Co-Executors of the Estate of Walter E. Disney, petitioners, v.
United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 77-5903. McArthur Corbitt, appellant, v. New Jersey. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart con-
curring in judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77-991. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare, appellant, v. Grace Aznavorian, etc.; and
No. 77–5999. Grace Aznavorian, etc., appellant, v. Joseph A.
Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Appeals
from the United States District Court for the Southern District of
California. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the United
States District Court for the Southern District of California for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the result.
No. 77-1388. Massachusetts, petitioner, v. Charles F. White. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.
Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77–6248. Jacquelyn E. Hunter, petitioner, v. Gerald Wallace
Dean, Sheriff. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia.
Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, January 8, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 77-1265. Marquette National Bank of Minneapolis, petitioner,
v. First of Omaha Service Corporation et al.; and
No. 77-1258. Minnesota, petitioner, v. First of Omaha Service Cor-
poration et al. On writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Minne-
sota. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 77-1202. Michigan. petitioner, v. Harold William Doran. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Michigan. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Michigan for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun concurring in the result with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall join.
Adjourned until Monday, January 8, 1979, at 10 o'clock.
