(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 8, 1979
319
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78–308. Mobay Chemical Corporation, appellant v. Douglas
Costle, Administrator, United States Environmental Protection
Agency. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Western
District of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1567. Violet Josephine Fay Buck, appellant v. Florence
Sylvia Wetherall Hunter et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of
New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question. Mr. Justice Brennan would note probable jurisdiction and set
case for oral argument.
No. 78–343. John L. Grady and Fatima Grady, appellants, v. Rod-
erick A. McLean. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
No. 78–621. Village of Carpentersville, appellant v. Edward Limp-
eris, Trustee. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ
of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-741. Dorothy H. Futch, appellant, v. Mary K. O'Leary.
Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-5508. Steven Jerome Drew, appellant, v. Louisiana. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for
280-278-78-37

378
MONDAY, JANUARY 8, 1979
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken
as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–5660. Roy Charles Bell, Sr., appellant, v. Clarice Bell
Church et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of juisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–5662. Nancy Jewell Cross, appellant, v. Frederick E. Alzo-
fon and Norma Alzofon. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-360. Galen Lee Randolph and Duque Williams, appellants,
v. Municipal Court, Southern Judicial District, County of San Mateo,
et al. (California, Real Party in Interest). Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, First Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would reverse the convic-
tions.
No. 78-580. Richard Garcia et al., appellants, v. Uvalde County et
al.; and
No. 78–731. United States, appellant, v. Uvalde County et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Western District
of Texas. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set cases for oral
argument.
No. 78–649. City of Boston et al., appellants, v. Richard L. Ander-
son et al. Appeal from the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell
would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
No. 78–816. David Bell, appellant v. New York State Liquor Au-
thority. Appeal from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of
New York, Third Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for
want of jurisdiction.
No. 78–5290. Robert Emerson Ezzell, appellant, v. Los Angeles
County Department of Adoptions. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
California. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 78-5357. Herman Caldwell, appellant, v. Helen Kaquatosh,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice

MONDAY, JANUARY 8, 1979
329
Brennan and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction
and set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-571. Gerald L. Blucher, petitioner, v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court
for the District of Wyoming with directions to vacate its judgment and
dismiss indictment. Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr.
Justice Rehnquist dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 77, Original. State of Tennessee, plaintiff, v. State of Arkansas.
It is ordered that the Honorable Earl R. Larson, Senior Judge of the
United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, is ap-
pointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time and
conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subse-
quent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue sub-
poenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he
may deem necessary to call for. The master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical stenographic and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion
as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court.
No. A-601. Carl L. Lynch et al., applicants, v. United States Appli-
cation for stay of mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall
and referred to the Court, denied.
No. D-70. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerome Weber. Disbar-
ment entered.
No. D-124. In the Matter of Disbarment of George G. Lindsay.
Disbarment entered.
No. 77-922. Chrysler Corporation, petitioner, v. Harold Brown,
Secretary of Defense, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to file a
supplemental brief, after argument, granted.

320
MONDAY, JANUARY 8, 1979
No. 77-1497. Arkansas, petitioner, v. Lonnie James Sanders. Mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed further herein in forma pau-
peris granted. Motion for appointment of counsel granted and it is
ordered that Jack T. Lassiter, Esquire, of Little Rock, Arkansas, is
appointed to serve as counsel for respondent in this case.
No. 77-1575. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, v.
Midwest Video Corporation et al.;
No. 77-1648. American Civil Liberties Union, petitioner, v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission et al.; and
No. 77-1662. National Black Media Coalition et al., petitioners, v.
Midwest Video Corporation et al. Motion of Solicitor General to dis-
pense with printing appendix granted.
No. 77-1578. Broadcast Music, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Columbia
Broadcasting System, Inc., et al.; and
No. 77-1583. American Society of Composers, Authors and Pub-
lishers, et al., petitioners, v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., et al.
Motion of National Broadcasting Company, Inc. for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of American Broacasting Com-
panies, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion
of National Religious Broadcasters, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Motion of All-Industry Television Music Li-
cense Committee for leave to participate in oral argument, as amicus
curiae, denied.
No. 77-1652. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, petitioner,
v. Shell Oil Company et al.; and
No. 77–1654. Consumer Energy Council of America, petitioner, v.
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Motion of Solicitor General
for additional time for oral argument denied. Mr. Justice Stewart
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 77-1806. Ford Motor Company, etc., petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. Motion of respondent UAW Local 588
for additional time for oral argument denied. Alternative request for
divided argument granted.
No. 77-6949. Robert Dunn, petitioner, v. United States. Motion for

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77–1378. Japan Line Ltd., et al., appellants, v. County of Los
Angeles et al. One and one half hours allowed for oral argument.
Argued by Mr. Peter L. Briger for the appellants, by Mr. Kent L.
Jones, pro hac vice, for the United States, as amicus curiae, by special
leave of Court, and by Mr. James Dexter Clark for the appellees.
No. 77-1359. United States, petitioner, v. Kimbell Foods, Inc., et
al. Argued by Mr. Stephen R. Barnett for the petitioner and by Mr.
Vernon O. Teofan for the respondents.
No. 77-1644. United States, petitioner, v. Zac A. Crittenden, Jr.,
dba Crittenden Tractor Company. Argued by Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
for the petitioner and by Mr. Howell Hollis, III, for the respondent.
No. 76-1309. United States, petitioner, v. Alfredo L. Caceres.
Argument commenced by Mr. Kenneth S. Geller for the petitioner
and continued by Mr. James J. Brosnahan for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JANUARY 9, 1979
359
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 77-1051. Bessie B. Givhan, petitioner, v. Western Line Con-
solidated School District et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 77-891. Aldo Colautti, Secretary of Department of Public
Welfare of Pennsylvania, et al., appellants, v. John Franklin et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Pennsylvania. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 77-6067. Billy Duren, petitioner, v. Missouri. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Missouri for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 77-1305. Parklane Hosiery Company, Inc., et al., petitioners,
v. Leo M. Shore. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, plaintiff, v. State of California
et al. On joint motion to enter supplemental decree and motions for
leave to intervene. Joint motion of United States, State of Arizona,
California Defendants, and State of Nevada to enter a supplemental
decree granted, and said present perfected rights in each State and
their priority dates determined. Decree entered and ordered filed. It is
further ordered that Judge Elbert P. Tuttle, Senior Judge, United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit be appointed Special
Master. It is further ordered that the motion of Fort Mojave Indian
Tribe et al. for leave to intervene, insofar as it seeks intervention to
oppose entry of the supplemental decree, denied. In all other respects
this motion and motion of Colorado River Indian Tribes et al. for
leave to intervene referred to the Special Master. Opinior per curiam
280-278-78-40

360
TUESDAY, JANUARY 9, 1979
announced by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Marshall took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 76–1309. United States, petitioner, v. Alfredo L. Caceres.
Argument continued by Mr. James J. Brosnahan for the respondent
and concluded by Mr. Kenneth S. Geller for the petitioner.
No. 77–926. Geraldine G. Cannon, petitioner, v. University of Chi-
cago et al. Argued by Mr. John M. Cannon for the petitioner, by Mr.
Solicitor General Wade H. McCree, Jr. for the federal respondents
supporting petitioner and by Mr. Stuart Bernstein for the non-federal
respondents.
No. 78, Original. State of California, plaintiff, v. State of Arizona
and the United States. Argued by Mr. Allan J. Goodman for Cali-
fornia, by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the United States, and by Mr.
Russell A. Kolsrud for Arizona.
No. 77–1439. William Riley Hughes, appellant, v. Oklahoma.
Argued by Mr. R. M. Helton for the appellant and by Mr. Bill J.
Bruce for the appellee.
No. 77-1722. Lawrence Dalia, petitioner, v. United States. Argu-
ment commenced by Mr. Louis A. Ruprecht for the petitioner.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice

ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77-1722. Lawrence Dalia, petitioner, v. United States. Argu-
ment concluded by Mr. Andrew L. Frey for the respondent.
No. 77-1575. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, v.
Midwest Video Corporation et al.;
No. 77-1648. American Civil Liberties Union, petitioner, v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission et al.; and
No. 77-1662. National Black Media Coaliton et al., petitioners,
v. Midwest Video Corporation et al. Argued by Mr. Lawrence G. Wal-
lace for the FCC et al. and by Mr. George H. Shapiro for Midwest
Video Corporation.
No. 77-1609. Terry Terrol Torres, appellant, v. Puerto Rico.
Argued by Mr. Joseph Remcho for the appellant and by Mr. Roberto
Armstrong, Jr., for the appellee.
No. 76–808. Gordon M. Ambach, as Commissioner of Education
of the State of New York, et al., appellants, v. Susan M. W. Norwick
et al. Argued by Mrs. Judith A. Gordon for the appellants and by Mr.
Bruce J. Ennis, Jr., for the appellees.
Adjourned until Monday, January 15, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1979
363
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 77-1618. Simon L. Leis, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Larry Flynt
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted,
judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice White would grant certiorari and set
case for oral argument. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77–6062. Emerson E. Harlin, petitioner, v. Missouri. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Supreme Court of Missouri for reconsideration in light of
Duren v. Missouri, 439 U.S. (1978). Opinion per curiam. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in judgment in this case and in
Nos. 77-6066, 77–6068, 77-6553, 77-6701 and 77-7012. Mr. Justice
Rehnquist dissents.
-
No. 77–6066. Vincent X. Lee, petitioner, v. Missouri; and
No. 77-6068. Eugene Minor, petitioner, v. Missouri. On petitions
for writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Missouri;
No. 77-6553. William Arrington, appellant, v. Missouri. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Missouri; and
No. 77-6701. Herbert Burnfin, petitioner, v. Missouri; and
No. 77-7012. Clifford R. Combs, petitioner, v. Missouri. On peti-
tions for writs of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kan-
sas City District. Motions for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari in Nos. 77-6066, 77–6068,
77–6701 and 77-7012 granted. Judgments vacated and cases remanded
to their respective courts for reconsideration in light of Duren v.
280-278-78-42

364
MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1979
Missouri, 439 U.S. — (1978). Opinion per curiam. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell concurring in judgments in these cases and in No. 77–
6062, ante. Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1688. LeRoy Symm, Tax Assessor-Collector of Waller
County, Texas, appellant, v. United States et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas.
Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun would note probable juris-
diction. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger joins. Mr. Justice Powell would dismiss appeal
for want of a properly presented federal question.
No. 78–523. Willie Bailey et al., appellants, v. J. Clayton Har-
grove, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Middle District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan and Mr. Justice Marshall dissent.
No. 78-609. John G. Cardwell, Jr., appellant, v. Village of Waite
Hill. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Lake County. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-5804. Joseph Genco, appellant, v. District of Columbia
National Bank. Appeal from the District of Columbia Court of
Appeals. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–821. Lucius Holloway, Sr., et al., appellants, v. Betty E.
Wise, etc., et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Middle District of Georgia. Judgment affirmed.
No. 78-5631. Hajji A. R. Ahmad, appellant, v. Michael Rodak,
Jr., Clerk, Supreme Court of the United States. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 78-5689. Hajji A. R. Ahmad et al., appellants, v. Louis Aytch
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern
District of Pennsylvania. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction.

States et al. Argument commenced by Mr. Clyde O. Martz for the
petitioners.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 77-753. International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs,
Warehousemen and Helpers of America, petitioner, v. John Daniel;
and
No. 77-754. Local 705, International Brotherhood of Teamsters,
Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, et al., petitioners,
v. John Daniel. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.
No. 77–920. Thor Power Tool Company, petitioner, v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

v. Pennzoil Producing Company et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to

return entire case to the Commission for further proceedings in con-

and Tribes of the Yakima Indian Nation. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and

Brennan joins.

MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1979
385
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-339. Robert Wilcox, Sheriff, Bonner County, appellant, v.
Harry T. Struve. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Idaho. The
appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-5814. Edward Wayland, appellant, v. Essex County Bank &
Trust Co., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–866. Vornado, Inc., et al., appellants, v. John J. Degnan,
Attorney General of New Jersey, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of New Jersey. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substan-
tial federal question.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-5606. Claude M. Hardy, petitioner, v. Missouri. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kan-
sas City District. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of
Missouri, Kansas City District are granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kansas City Dis-
trict, for further consideration in light of Duren v. Missouri,
U.S.
(1979) and Harlin v. Missouri,
— (1979).
U.S.
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Commonwealth of Ken-
tucky. Report of Special Master received and ordered filed. Excep-
tions, if any, with supporting briefs to the Report may be filed by the
parties within 45 days. Reply briefs, if any, to such exceptions may be
filed within 30 days.
280-278-78-46

386
MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1979
No. 79, Original. State of Oklahoma, plaintiff, v. State of
Arkansas. It is ordered that the Honorable William H. Becker, Senior
Judge of the United States District Court for the Western District of
Missouri, is appointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix
the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to
direct subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon wit-
nesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced
and such as he may deem necessary to call for. The master is directed.
to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion
as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have
same effect as if originally made by the Court.
No. D-140. In the Matter of Disbarment of Samuel B. Ray. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-156. In the matter of Disbarment of Eugene A. Falk. It is
ordered that Eugene A. Falk of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 77-983. Washington et al., petitioners, v. Washington State.
Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Association et al.; Washington
et al., petitioners, v. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al.;
No. 78-119. Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et
el.; and
No. 78–139. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al., petition-
ers, v. United States District Court for the Western District of Wash-
ington (United States et al., real parties in interest). Motion of Pacific
Seafood Processors Association for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted.
No. 77–1511. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Edu-
cation, and Welfare, petitioner, v. Evelyn Elliott et al. Motion of re-
spondents to dismiss or remand denied.
No. 78-6. Hilmar G. Moore et al., appellants, v. John Pleasant
Sims et al. Motion of John Quincy Carter, Esquire, for leave to present
oral argument, pro hac vice, denied. Motion of appellees for divided
argument denied.

MONDAY, JANUARY 22, 1979
OPINION
No. 77-533. Jess H. Hisquierdo, petitioner, v. Angela Hisquierdo.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.
Adjourned until Tuesday, February 20, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1979
401
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice
White, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-669. Ellsworth Freight Lines, Inc., et al., appellants, v.
Missouri Highway Reciprocity Commission et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of Missouri. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-809. Venola Walton, appellant, v. Small Business Adminis-
tration. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–1024. Jeanette P. Strongin, appellant, v. Ewald B. Nyquist,
Commissioner of Education of New York, et al. Appeal from the Court
of Appeals of New York. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdic-
tion. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition
for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-1048. Edward M. Murphy, II, appellant, v. Pennsylvania
State Board of Bar Examiners et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court
of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-883. Newman Signs, Inc., appellant, v. Walter R. Hjelle,
etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of North Dakota. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-955. Guido Condosta, appellant, v. Rosalie Condosta. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Vermont. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
280-278-79-47

402
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1979
No. 78–1010. City of Mountain View, Georgia, et al., appellants, v.
Clayton County, Georgia, et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
No. 78–1077. Valley International Properties, Inc., appellant, c.
Los Campeones, Inc. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas,
Thirteenth Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-1056. Hazel Ruth Logan et al., appellants, v. W. E. Strick-
land, Comr., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The
appeal is dismissed as moot.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 81, Original. Commonwealth of Kentucky, Plaintiff, v. State of
Indiana et al. Motion for leave to file bill of complaint granted and
defendants allowed sixty days in which to answer.
No. A-643. Stanley J. Kline et al., applicants, v. Pyms Suchman
Real Estate Co. et al. Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice
Marshall and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-710. Robert Jackson Snyder, applicant, v. United States.
Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Stewart and referred
to the Court, denied.
No. D–138. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul C. Mueller. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-159. In the Matter of Disbarment of Elijah W. Ratcliff. It
is ordered that Elijah W. Ratcliff, of Livingston, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court..
No. 77–983. Washington et al., petitioners, v. Washington State
Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Association et al.; Washington
et al., petitioners, v. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al.;
No. 78-119. Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et al.;
and
No. 78–139. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al., petitioners,
v. United States District Court for the Western District of Wash-
ington (United States et al., real parties in interest). Motion of Amer-
ican Friends Service Committee et al. for leave to file a brief, as
amici curiae, granted. Motion of Nez Perce Tribe of Idaho for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of the American Civil
Liberties Union et al. for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1979
403
No. 77–6673. Zackary C. Brown, appellant, v. Texas. Motion of
California for divided argument denied.
No. 78–91. R. W. Jones, Sr. et al., petitioners, v. Charles T. Wolf
et al. Motion of respondents for leave to file a supplemental brief after
argument, granted.
No. 78-233. Personnel Administrator of Massachusetts et al., ap.
pellants, v. Helen B. Feeney. Motion of Office of Personnel Manage-

APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED OR POSTPONED
No. 78–740. Cecil D. Andrus. Secretary of the Interior et al., ap-
pellants, v. L. Douglas Allard et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the District of Colorado. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted.
No. 78–630. Washington et al., appellants, v. Confederated Tribes
of the Colville Indian Reservation et al. Appeal from the United
States District Court for the Eastern District of Washington. Further
consideration of the question of jurisdiction is postponed to the hear-
ing of the case on the merits.
No. 78–952. Randal Rush et al., appellants, v. Jeffrey D. Savchuk.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted. Case set for oral argument in tandem with No. 78-
1078, World-Wide Volkswagen v. Woodson.

No. 78–1038. David H. Kubert, petitioner, v. Supreme Court of the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania;
No. 78–5858. Thomas W. Shaw, petitioner, v. Joe J. Fisher, Judge,
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, et al.;
and
No. 78-5938. L. P. Kibert, petitioner, v. United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motions for leave to file petitions for
writs of mandamus denied.
No. 78-1105. Nassar and Co., Inc. and George M. Nassar, petition-
ers, v. United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit et al.
Motion for leave to file petition for writ
of mandamus and for other relief denied.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1979

leave to file petition for writ of prohibition denied.

v. Public Utilities Commission of California et al.;

v. Public Utilities Commission of California et al.;

al.; and
No. 78-5794. Randolph Joseph X. Greene, petitioner, v. United
States. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 76–1694. Mobil Oil Corporation, petitioner, v. Harry Lightcap
et al. Motion of Continental Oil Company for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Petition for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion and petition.

No. 78-5512. William Nicholas, petitioner, v. Tennessee Depart-
ment of Employment Security et al. Motions for leave to file petitions.

OPINIONS
Movant
Robert E. Moss.
Rex E. Lee.
Jerome Cohen.
Charles Foster
Knight.
No. 77–1410. William E. Butner, petitioner, v. United States et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1979
447
No. 77–1465. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Genevieve O. Ras-
mussen et al.; and
No. 77-1491. Geo Control, Incorporated and New Hampshire In-
surance Company, petitioners, v. Genevieve O. Rasmussen et al. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
No. 77–1163. E. Richard Friedman et al., appellants, v. N. Jay
Rogers et al.;
No. 77–1164. N. Jay Rogers et al., appellants, v. E. Richard Fried-
man et al.; and
No. 77-1186. Texas Optometric Association, Inc., appellant, v.
N. Jay Rogers et al. Appeals from the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed in part and re-
versed in part and cases remanded to the United States District Court
for the Eastern District of Texas for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens joined and in Part III of which Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr.
Justice Blackmun joined. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77–1680. Michigan, petitioner, v. Gary DeFillippo. Argued by
Mr. Timothy A. Baughman for the petitioner and by Mr. James C.
Howarth for the respondent.
No. 77–6673. Zackary C. Brown, appellant, v. Texas. Argued by
Mr. Raymond C. Caballero for the appellant and by Mr. Renea Hicks
for the appellee, pro hac vice, by special leave of Court.
No. 78-58. G. Garvin Brown, III, petitioner, v. Mark Paul Felsen.
Argued by Mr. Craig A. Christensen for the petitioner and by Mr.
Alex Stephen Keller for the respondent.
No. 78–225. Bruce Babbitt, Governor of the State of Arizona, et al.,
appellants, v. United Farm Workers National Union, etc., et al. One
hour and twenty minutes allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr.
Rex E. Lee for the appellants and by Jerome Cohen for the appellees.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1979
449
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 77-742. Jerome Miller, etc., et al., appellants, v. Marcel
Youakim et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall, Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 77-1134. Montana et al., appellants, v. United States. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Montana.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of Montana for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Mar-
shall. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White.
No. 77-1248. Illinois State Board of Elections, appellant, v.
Socialist Workers Party et al. Appeal from the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurs in judgment.
Concurring by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist concurring in judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens con-
curring in judgment.
No. 77-1254. Cyrus R. Vance, Secretary of State, et al., appellants,
v. Holbrook Bradley et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Columbia. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Marshall.
No. 77–654. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, Inc., petitioner,
v. Federal Trade Commission. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart. Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in part and dis-
senting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall dissenting in part.
Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
280-278-78-50

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1979
450
No. 78, Original. State of California, plaintiff, v. State of Arizona
and the United States. On motion for leave to file bill of complaint.
Motion for leave to file bill of complaint granted and defendants
allowed 45 days in which to answer or otherwise respond. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart.
No. 77-1652. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, petitioner,
v. Shell Oil Company et al.; and
No. 77-1654. Consumer Energy Council of America, petitioner, v.
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed by an equally divided Court. Opinion per curiam announced
by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77-6540. Harold Ramsey, petitioner, v. New York. Argued by
Mr. Steven W. Fisher for the petitioner and by Mr. Richard Elliot
Mischel for the respondent.
No. 78-17. United Gas Pipe Line Company, petitioner, v. Billy J.
McCombs et al.; and
No. 78-249. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, petitioner,
v. Billy J. McCombs et al. Argued by Mr. Richard A. Allen for the
petitioner in No. 78–249, by Mr. Knox Bemis for the petitioner in N.
78–17, and by Mr. Stanley L. Cunningham for the respondents in both
cases.
No. 78-90. Daniel Burch et al., petitioners, v. Louisiana. Argued by
Mr. Jack Peebles for the petitioners and by Mrs. Louise Korns for the
respondent.
No. 77-1554. County Court of Ulster County, New York, et al.,
petitioners, v. Samuel Allen et al. Argued by Mrs. Eileen Shapiro for
the petitioners and by Mr. Michael Young for the respondents.
Adjourned until Monday, February 26, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1979
453
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 78-443. Harrah Independent School District et al., petitioners,
v. Mary Jane Martin. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted, judgment is reversed, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Mr. Justice Marshall con-
curs in the result.
No. 78-551. United States, petitioner, v. Bodcaw Company. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES

280-278-79-52

454
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1979
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-157. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert B. Mitchell, Jr.
It is ordered that Robert B. Mitchell, Jr., of Bethlehem, Pennsylvania,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-158. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold C. Herman.
It is ordered that Harold C. Herman, of Woodmere, New York, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-160. In the Matter of Disbarment of Aaron R. Fodiman.
It is ordered that Aaron R. Fodiman, of Arlington, Virginia, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-161. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bong Hyun Kim. It
is ordered that Bong Hyun Kim, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

curiae, granted.

Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion for leave to file
petition for writ of mandamus denied. Mr. Justice Stevens took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

the appellants and by Mr. Jan E. Unna for the appellees.

pellants, v. Helen B. Feeney. Argued by Mr. Thomas R. Kiley for the
appellants and by Mr. Richard P. Ward for the appellee.

Sims et al. Argued by Mr. David H. Young for the appellants and
by Ms. Windell E. C. Porter for the appellees.

petitioners, v. Leroy Foust. Argued by Mr. Laurence J. Cohen for the
petitioners and by Mr. Terry W. Mackey for the respondent.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1979
(JOURNAL)
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
bat es
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ADMISSIONS TO THE BAR ON ORAL MOTIONS
Applicant
City and State
Joan Carol Schmidt
Carll Joseph Kretsinger
Boston, Mass.
Dallas, Tex.
Michael Adrian Harring
Annandale, Va.
Scott Carson Moriearty
Boston, Mass.
Movant
Joseph J. Balliro
Thomas William
Peterson
William Frank
Robinson, Jr.
John H. Henn
OPINION
No. 77–952. Group Life and Health Insurance Company, etc., et al.,
petitioners, v. Royal Drug Company, Inc., etc., et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger,
Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell join.
The Chief Justice said:
"I am authorized to announce that Mr. Henry Putzel who has been
the official Reporter of Decisions of the Court for 15 years has retired.
"The work of the Reporter of Decisions is not known to the public
but is of great importance to the courts, the legal profession and to the
public. Mr. Putzel has performed the exacting duties of that impor-
tant office with great distinction and in keeping with the tradition of
the twelve men who preceded him in that position. The Court wishes.
pay tribute to him and wish him well for the years ahead.
"Mr. Henry Lind, Mr. Putzel's deputy, has been appointed to suc-
ceed him."
to
Oral ArguMENT

Joseph J. Balliro and Mr. John H. Henn for the appellees in both
cases.
ORDER
It is ordered that Henry C. Lind be appointed Reporter of Decisions
of this Court to succeed Henry Putzel, Jr., effective at the commence-
ment of business February 25, 1979, and he is charged with the duty of
reporting the decisions of the present term which have not been re-
ported prior to February 25, 1979.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINION
No. 77-1413. Jane Aronson, petitioner, v. Quick Point Pencil
Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun concerning in the result.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 77-983. Washington et al., petitioners, v. Washington State
Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Association et al.; Washington
et al., petitioners, v. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al.;
No. 78–119. Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et al.;
and
No. 78–139. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al., Peti-
tioners, v. United States District Court for the Western District of
Washington (United States et al., real parties in interest). One and
one half hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Slade Gor-
ton for the State of Washington, by Mr. Philip A. Lacovara for the
Associations of Non-Indian Fishermen, by Mr. Mason D. Morisset
for the Indian Tribes, and by Mr. Louis F. Claiborne for the United
States et al.
280-278-79-54

472
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1979
No. 78–275. Oscar Mayer & Co. et al., petitioners, v. Joseph W.
Evans. Argued by Mr. James W. Gladden, Jr. for the petitioners, by
Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr., for the United States, as amicus curiae, sup-
porting respondent, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Mark W.
Bennett for the respondent.
No. 77–1806. Ford Motor Company, etc., petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. Argued by Mr. Theophil C. Kammholz
for the petitioner, by Mr. Norton J. Come for the respondent NLRB,
and by Mr. John A. Fillion for the respondent UAW Local 588.
Adjourned until Monday, March 5, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1979
473
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 77-1255. James C. Anders, etc., appellant, v. Jesse J. Floyd.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
South Carolina. Motion of Legal Defense Fund for Unborn Children
for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of David
Gaetano for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of South Carolina for further consideration in light of
Colautti v. Franklin, 439 U.S. (1979). Opinion per curiam. Mr.
Justice Stewart dissents.
No. 77-1659. The Chase Manhattan Bank, N. A., petitioner, v. The
Finance Administration of the City of New York et al.; Citibank,
N. A., petitioner, v. The City of New York Finance Administration.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New
York. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this court. Opinion per
curiam.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1257. Walter D. Schmier, appellant, v. Trustees of Cali-
fornia State University and Colleges et al. Appeal from the Court of
Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate District. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–642. Richard L. Thornburgh, Governor, et al., appellants, v.
Robert E. Casey, etc., et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable
jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
280-278-79-55

474
MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1979
No. 78-683. Century 21 Real Estate Corporation et al., appellants,
v. Nevada Real Estate Advisory Commission et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the District of Nevada. Motion of
United States Trademark Association for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. Judgment affirmed.
No. 78–762. Samuel Kraham, appellant, v. Florida. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice.
Marshall would reverse the conviction.
No. 78-1102. John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General of Missouri, et
al., appellants, v. Michael Freiman et al. Appeal from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Motion of Legal
Defense Fund for Unborn Children for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, denied. Motion of Alan Ernest for appointment as counsel for
children unborn and born alive denied. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist would note probable jurisdiction and
set case for oral argument.
No. 78-5760. Albert H. Carter, appellant, v. Texas; Albert H. Car-
ter, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal from the Court of Criminal Appeals
of Texas. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-5833. Jose Gonzalez, appellant, v. New York. Appeal from
the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, First
Judicial Department. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Marshall would note probable jurisdiction and set case for oral
argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77–580. Phillip M. Proctor et al., petitioners, v. State Farm
Mutual Automobile Insurance Company et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con-
sideration in light of Group Life v. Royal Drug Co., 440 U.S.
(1979).

OPINIONS
No. 77-1327. Lake Country Estates, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Tahoe Regional Planning Agency, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed in part and affirmed in part and case remanded to the Court of

490
MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1979
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Brennan dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall dis-
senting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun dissenting in part,
in Part I of which Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 77-1337. Nevada et al., petitioners, v. John Michael Hall, etc.,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Dissenting opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger
joins.
No. 77-841. Arthur F. Quern, etc., petitioner, v. John Jordan, etc.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehni-
quist. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment, in
parts I, II and III of which Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Marshall concurring in judgment.
No. 77-1177. Aubrey Scott, petitioner, v. Illinois. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun.
No. 77–968. Detroit Edison Company, petitioner, v. National Labor
Relations Board. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart joined by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell
and Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and in which Mr. Justice Stevens joined
except in Part II-A. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join, and in
Part I of which Mr. Justice Stevens joins.
No. 77-1119. William Herbert Orr, appellant, v. Lillian M. Orr.
Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.

MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1979
491
No. 77-6540. Harold Ramsey, petitioner, v. New York. On writ of
certiorari to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New
York, Second Judicial Department. Writ of certiorari dismissed as
improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, March 19, 1979, at 19 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1979
493
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-421. Dahlberg Electronics, Inc., et al., appellants, v. George
Kievlan et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, First
Appellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 78–1091. Lina Love, appellant, v. Lester Maynard. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-1119. Gabriel A. Fazekas, appellant, v. University of
Houston et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, First
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question.
No. 78–1285. Mark Charles Floyd, appellant, v. Arizona. Appeal
from the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division Two. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-6102. Fred Abken, appellant, v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
1. from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-721. Arthur F. Quern, etc., et al., appellants, v. Juan
Hernandez et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois. Motion of appellees Juan Hernandez
et ux., etc. for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Judg-
ment affirmed.
No. 78-1160. Theodore R. Saker et ux., appellants, v. Harpster
Bank. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Franklin County.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
280-278-79-57

494
MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1979
No. 78-5844. Karen Elaine Farrell, appellant, v. Glenn Dale John-
son. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall would note probable
jurisdiction and set case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 77-1653. Theodore Q. Childs, petitioner, v. Lucy Gant Childs.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division of the
Supreme Court of New York, Second Judicial Department. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded
to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, Second
Judicial Department, for further consideration in light of Orr v. Orr,
440 U.S. (1979). Mr. Justice Stewart dissents.

No. 77–1786. Eugene James Loyacano, petitioner, v. Neila Le
Blanc, etc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Louisiana. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Louisiana for further
consideration in light of Orr v. Orr, 440 U.S.

(1979).

denied.

cants, v. Carl B. Rubin, Judge, etc. Application for stay, presented
to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr.
Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of this
application.

No. 78–303. William E. Colby and Vernon A. Walters, petitioners,
v. Rodney D. Driver et al. Motion of Solicitor General for divided
argument granted.
No. 78-349. United States, petitioner, v. Henry Helstoski; and
No. 78-546. Henry Helstoski, petitioner, v. H. Curtis Meanor,
United States District Judge, et al. Motion of Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr.,
et al. for leave to participate in oral arguments, as amici curiae,
granted, and 15 additional minutes allotted for that purpose.

Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr.
Justice Stevens would grant this motion. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.

petitioner, v. Brian F. Weber et al.;

for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of South-
eastern Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Motion of United States Justice Foundation for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Great Plains Legal
Foundation for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion
of Government Contract Employers Association for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied. Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.

MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1979

lotted 10 additional minutes for oral argument.
No. 78–749. Kentucky, petitioner, v. Harold Whorton. Consid-
eration of respondent's suggestion of mootness deferred to hearing of
case on the merits.
No. 78-759. David H. Leroy, Attorney General of Idaho, et al.,
appellants, v. Great Western United Corporation. Motion of National
Association of Insurance Commissioners for leave to file a brief, as

of Attorney General of Ohio for leave to participate in oral argument,
as amicus curiae, denied.
No. 78-1177. White Mountain Apache Tribe et al., petitioners, v.
Robert M. Bracker et al. Solicitor General invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 78–1277. William Irvin Golding, Sr., petitioner, v. City Coun-
cil of the City of Richmond et al. Application for stay, addressed to
Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, denied.
No. 78–5283. James A. Jackson, petitioner, v. Virginia et al. Mo-
tion of Attorney General of California for leave to participate in oral
argument, as amicus curiae, denied.
No. 78-6198. Leona M. Hudak, petitioner, v. Curators of the Uni-
versity of Missouri et al. Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice
Marshall and referred to the Court, denied.

Workers of America et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.

507
is actively pursuing his right to a writ of habeas corpus, [he] will
not be executed." Respondent's Brief in Opposition, at 3.
No. 78-1049. Aliquippa and Southern Railroad Company et al.,
petitioners, v. United States et al.; and
No. 78-1069. Baltimore and Ohio Chicago Terminal Railroad
Company et al., petitioners, v. United States et al. Petitions for writs
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of these petitions.
No. 78-1178. Director, Office Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Jacksonville Ship-
yards, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Black-
mum would grant certiorari.

writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall.

No. 77-1511. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Edu-
cation, and Welfare, petitioner, v. Evelyn Elliott et al. Argued by
Mr. Peter Buscemi for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special leave
of Court, and by Mr. Stanley E. Levin for the respondents.
No. 77–1844. City of Mobile, Alabama, et al., appellants v. Wiley
L. Bolden et al.; and
No. 78-357. Robert R. Williams et al., appellants, v. Leila G. Brown
et al. Two hours allowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Charles
S. Rhyne for the appellants in No. 77-1844, by Mr. James U. Black-
sher for the appellees in No. 77-1844, by Mr. James P. Turner for
the United States, as amicus curiae, supporting appellees in both cases,
by Mr. William H. Allen for the appellants in No. 78-357 and by
Mr. Eric Schnapper for the appellees in No. 78-357.
No. 78–479. Stanley D. Edmonds, petitioner, v. Compagnie Gen-
erale Transatlantique. Argued by Mr. Calvin W. Breit for the peti-
tioner and by Mr. Charles F. Tucker for the respondent.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 77-1172. National Muffler Dealers Associaton, Inc., petitioner,
v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 77-1489. New Jersey, petitioner, v. Joseph S. Portash. On
writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate
Division. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice
Marshall joins. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Black-
mun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT

Publishing Co., etc., et al. Argued by Mr. Cletus B. Hanley for the
petitioners and by Mr. Floyd Abrams for the respondent.

et al., petitioners, v. Harry Lewis. Argued by Mr. John M. Anderson
for the petitioners, by Mr. Eric L. Keisman for the respondent, and
by Mr. Ralph C. Ferrara for the Securities and Exchange Commis-
sion, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice

OPINIONS
No. 77-961. New York Telephone Company et al., petitioners, v.
New York State Department of Labor et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Mr. Justice Stevens announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered an opinion in which Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Rehnquist joined. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the
result. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Powell with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice
Stewart join.
No. 77-1427. New York City Transit Authority et al., petitioners,
v. Carl A. Beazer et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and dis-
senting in part. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
joins.
No. 77–752. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. The
Catholic Bishop of Chicago et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan with whom Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall
and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.

524
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21, 1979

by Ms. Carolyn J. Colville for the petitioner, pro hac vice, by special
leave of Court, and by Mr. J. Marshall Coleman for the respondents.
Adjourned until Monday, March 26, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1979
525
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78-1013. Peggy J. Connor et al., petitioners, v. J. P. Cole-
man, Judge, United States Court of Appeals, et al. On motion for
leave to file petition for writ of mandamus. Motion for leave to file
petition for writ of mandamus granted. The United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Mississippi is instructed,
forthwith and without further delay, to adopt a final plan for the
reapportionment of the Mississippi Legislature. Our consideration of
the petition for writ of mandamus is continued for 30 days. Opinion
per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the decision of this motion.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-846. First of Omaha Service Corporation of Omaha,
Nebraska, etc., et al., appellants, v. Iowa ex rel., Richard C. Turner,
Attorney General. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Iowa. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Iowa for
further consideration in light of Marquette National Bank v. First of
Omaha Corporation, 439 U.S.-(1979). Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-1126. Joseph Hoagland et al., appellants, v. Minnesota.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Minnesota. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 78-156. United States, petitioner, v. Hugh J. Addonizio et
al. Motion of respondents for divided argument granted Mr. Justice.
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
280-278-79- -61

526
MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1979
No. 78–432. United States Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-
CLC, petitioner, v. Brian F. Weber et al.; and
No. 78-435. Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation, petitioner,
v. Brian F. Weber et al.; and
No. 78–436. United States et al., petitioners, v. Brian F. Weber
et al. Motion of Affirmative Action Coordinating Center et al. for
leave to participate in oral argument, as amici curiae, denied. Mr.
Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this motion.
No. 78–437. Joseph A. Califano, Secretary of Health, Education
and Welfare, appellant, v. Cindy Westcott et al.; and
No. 78–689. Alexander Sharp, II, etc., appellant, v. Cindy West-
cott et al. Motion of American Civil Liberties Union et al. for leave
to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78–1359. Feridun Gunduy, petitioner, v. United States. Ap-
plication for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred to
the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this application.
No. 78-5981. Francis Rick Ferri, petitioner, v. Daniel Ackerman.
Motion of petitioner for appointment of counsel granted and it is or-
dered that Julian N. Eule, Esquire, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is
appointed to serve as counsel for petitioner in this case. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 78–1143. Cyrus Vance, Secretary of State of the United States,
appellant, v. Laurence J. Terrazas. Appeal from the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of appellee for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case probable juris-
diction noted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this matter.
No. 78-5937. Ventura E. Ybarra, appellant, v. Illinois. Appeal
from the Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District. Motion of ap-
pellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. In this case
probable jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration of this matter.

consideration or decision of this petition.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 2, 1979, until
Monday, April 16, 1979.

OPINIONS
No. 77–1686. Leo Sheep Company et al., petitioners, v. United
States et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Justice
White took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 77-1571. Delaware, petitioner, v. William J. Prouse III. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Delaware Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Powell joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 77-1553. County of Los Angeles et al., petitioners, v. Van
Davis et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for entry of an appropriate order directing the
United States District Court for the Central District of California
to dismiss the action as moot. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT

No. 78-546. Henry Helstoski, petitioner, v. H. Curtis Meanor,

lowed for oral argument. Argued by Mr. Morton Stavis for the peti-
tioner in No. 78-546 and the respondent in No. 78-349, by Mr. Stanley
M. Brand for Thomas P. O'Neill, Jr., Speaker of the House et al., as

544
TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1979
amici curiae, by special leave of Court, and By Mr. Solicitor General
Wade H. McCree, Jr. for the respondents in No. 78-546 and the peti-
tioner in No. 78–349.
No. 78–488. United States, petitioner, v. 564.54 Acres of Land (more
or less, situated in Monroe and Pike Counties, Pennsylvania, et al.
Argued by Mr. Stephen R. Barnett for the petitioner and by Mr. H.
Ober Hess for the respondents.

and by Mr. R. Gene Braswell for the respondent.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1979
547
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1833. Sun Oil Company of Pennsylvania, appellant, v.
Unemployment Compensation Board of Review of Pennsylvania et al.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 78–1243. Jean L. Wernet, appellant, v. Minnesota. Appeal
from the District Court of Minnesota, Fourth Judicial District. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-1225. Adina Etkes, appellant, v. Bartell Media Corpora-
tion et al. Appeal from the Court of Appeal of California, Second Ap-
pellate District. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for
writ of certiorari, certiorari is denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–1255. Harry B. Helmsley et al., appellants, v. Borough of
Fort Lee et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Motion
of National Association of Realtors for leave to file a brief, as amicus
curiae, granted. Motion of National Apartment Association for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for
want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Powell took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-558. John F. Kretchmar, petitioner, v. Nebraska. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nebraska. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to
280-278-79-65

548
MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1979
the Supreme Court of Nebraska for further consideration in light of
Delaware v. Prouse, 440 U.S. - (1979). Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. 77-1465. Director, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs,
United States Department of Labor, petitioner, v. Genevieve O. Ras-
mussen et al.; and
No. 77-1491. Geo Control, Incorporated and New Hampshire In-
surance Company, petitioners, v. Genevieve O. Rasmussen et al. Motion
of respondents award of attorneys' fees denied. Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78–223. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Bap-
tist Hospital, Inc. Motion of Local 150-T Service Employees Inter-
national Union (AFL-CIO), for divided argument granted. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78–605. United States et al.. petitioners, v. Glen L. Rutherford
et al. Motion of National Health Federation for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78-711. Southeastern Community College, petitioner, v.
Frances B. Davis. Motion of The Board of Governors of the Univer-
sity of North Carolina for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Mr. Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78-753. Great American Federal Savings & Loan Association
et al., petitioners, v. John R. Novotny. Joint motion of Solicitor Gen-
eral, as amicus curiae, and respondent for divided argument granted.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 78–1102. John D. Ashcroft, Attorney General of Missouri, et
al., appellants v. Michael Freiman. et al. Motion of appellees for award
of attorneys' fees and costs denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78-1369. Committee for Public Education and Religious Lib-
erty et al., appellants, v. Edward V. Regan, etc., et al. Application for
stay, presented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the
Court. denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this application.
No. 78–1443. Kitty Louise Strouse and Robert D. Winter, petition-
ers, v. Bette J. Winter. Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall and referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.

No. 77-1625. Image Carrier Corporation et al., petitioners, v.

leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. Petition for writ of cer-

denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision
of these motions and petition.

557
County, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stewart would

part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

low, Chief Judge, United States District Court for the District of New

motion.

OPINIONS
No. 76–1309. United States, petitioner, v. Alfredo L. Caceres. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.

MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1979
567
No. 77-1359. United States, petitioner, v. Kimbell Foods, Inc.,
et al.; and
No. 77-1644. United States, petitioner, v. Zac A. Crittenden, Jr.,
dba Crittenden Tractor Company. On writs of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment in No.
77-1359 affirmed. Judgment in No. 77-1644 vacated and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall.
No. 77-1575. Federal Communications Commission, petitioner, v.
Midwest Video Corporation et al.;
No. 77-1648. American Civil Liberties Union, petitioner, v. Fed-
eral Communications Commission et al.; and
No. 77-1662. National Black Media Coalition et al., petitioners,
v. Midwest Video Corporation et al. On writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
Adjourned until Monday, April 16, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

FRIDAY, APRIL 13, 1979
569
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-868. Betty Evans, individually and as next friend acting
on behalf of John Louis Evans III, applicant, . Larry Bennett, Com-
missioner. Alabama Correctional System, et al. Application for stay
of execution, presented to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and by him referred
to the Court, denied. Concurring statement by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this application.
