(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1979
571
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1071. Raymond Hughes, appellant, v. Madge J. Hughes.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Alabama. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further consider-
ation in light of Orr v. Orr, 440 U.S. — (1979). Mr. Justice Powell took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–1451. James J. McCoy and Eileen R. Rasulis, appellants, v.
Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare,
et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-1611. Hercoform, Incorporated, petitioner, v. Chicago Title
Insurance Company et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of United States
v. Kimbell Foods, Inc., 440 U.S. (1979). Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
-
No. 78–5995. Tommy L. Hunt, petitioner, v. Missouri; and
No. 78–6077. Lavance C. Jones, petitioner, v. Missouri. On motions
for writs of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kansas City
District. Motions of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petitions for writs of certiorari granted. Judgments vacated and
cases remanded to the Court of Appeals of Missouri, Kansas City Dis-
trict, for further consideration in light of Duren v. Missouri, 439
U.S. (1979). Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of these cases.
-
280-278-79-68

572
MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1979
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-835. United Steelworkers of America, applicant, v. Joseph
Solien et al. Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan
and referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this application.
No. 80. Original. State of Colorado, plaintiff, v. State of New Mex-
ico and Toney Anaya, Attorney General of State of New Mexico. It
is ordered that the Honorable Ewing I. Kerr, Senior Judge for the
United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, is ap-
pointed Special Master in this case with authority to fix the time and
conditions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subse-
quent proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue sub-
poenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he
may deem necessary to call for. The master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such propor-
tion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have
the same effect as if originally made by the Court.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this matter.
No. 78–599. Secretary of the Navy et al., petitioners, v. Frank L.
Huff et al.; and
No. 78–1006. Harold R. Brown, Secretary of Defense, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Albert Edward Glines. Motion of Solicitor General to con-
solidate the cases for briefing and oral argument denied. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78–605. United States et al., petitioners, v. Glen L. Rutherford
et al. Motion of Save the United States Movement, Improving Public
Health and Physical Fitness of the United States Citizens, for leave
to participate in oral argument, as amicus curiae, denied. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 78–610. Columbus Board of Education et al., petitioners, v.
Gary L. Penick et al. Motion of Cleveland Board of Education for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of Solicitor
General for divided argument, as amicus curiae, granted. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.

MONDAY, APRIL 16, 1979
573
No. 78-627. Dayton Board of Education, et al., petitioners, v.
Mark Brinkman et al. Motion of Cleveland Board of Education for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, denied. Motion of Solicitor
General for divided argument, as amicus curiae, granted. Mr. Justice
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 78–776. United States, petitioner, v. Milton Dean Batchelder.
Motion of Solicitor General to permit Andrew J. Levander, Esquire,
to present oral argument, pro hac vice, granted. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
CERTIORARI GRANTED

of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Ohio granted. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Town Court Nursing Center et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 78–1323. Norfolk and Western Railway Company, petitioner,
v. Kandythe J. Liepelt, Administratrix, etc. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, granted. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
petition.
No. 78-1088. Henry A. Kissinger, petitioner, v. Reporters Com-
mittee for Freedom of the Press et al.; and
No. 78-1217. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press et al.,
petitioners v. Henry A. Kissinger. Petitions for writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia'
Circuit granted. Cases consolidated and a total of one hour allotted
for oral argument. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these petitions.
No. 78-5471. Thomas W. Whalen, petitioner, v. United States;
James E. Pynes, petitioner v. United States. Motion of Thomas W.
Whalen leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals in Whalen v.
United States, No. 8583, granted. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.

tin Hudspeth. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion and petition.

Institute at Tehachapi, petitioner, v. Lawrence S. Bittaker. Motion of
respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considertaion or
decision of this motion and petition.
No. 78-1103. Pennsylvania, petitioner, v. Melvin H. Ritter, Jr.
Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania,
Middle District, denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this motion and petition.
No. 78–1098. Richard P. Herman, petitioner, v. United States. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Third Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall would grant certiorari. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 78–1290. Arthur Goldstein, petitioner, v. City of Norfolk. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia denied.
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
would grant certiorari and reverse the conviction. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 78-5873. John Buford Irving, III, petitioner, v. Mississippi.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi
denied. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr.
Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this petition.
No. 78–6091. Johnny Lewis Washington, petitioner, v. Mississippi.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Mississippi
denied. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this petition.
No. 78–6253. Eddie William Finney, petitioner, v. Georgia. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied.
Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision.
of this petition.

OPINIONS
No. 78-90. Daniel Burch et al., petitioners, v. Louisiana. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed in
part and affirmed in part and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
Louisiana for further proceeding not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Concurring opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in
part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr.
Justice Marshall join.
No. 76–808. Gordon M. Ambach, as Commissioner of Education
of the State of New York, et al., appellants, v. Susan M. W. Norwick
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern
District of New York. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Blackmun with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and
Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 77–1493. Gladstone Realtors et al., petitioners, v. Village of
Bellwood et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
280-278-79-70

598
Tuesday, April 17, 1979
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed with exception as
noted in opinion of the Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissent-
ing opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stewart
joins.
No. 77-874. Genanett Alexander et al., petitioners, v. United States
Department of Housing and Urban Development et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit; and
No. 77–1463. Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Housing and
Urban Development, et al., petitioners, v. Sadie E. Cole et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit. Judgment in No. 77-874 affirmed. Judgment in No.
77-1463 reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 77-1578. Broadcast Music, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Colum-

Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1979
601
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1374. Andy Martin, appellant, v. Board of County Com-
missioners of Lee County, Florida, et al. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Florida. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan would note probable jurisdic
tion and set case for oral argument.
No. 78–6060. Darryl Leroy Elam, appellant, v. Virginia. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 78-79. General Dynamics Corporation, petitioner, v. Ray
Marshall et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further consideration in light of Chrysler Corporation v.
Brown, 441 U.S. ——— (1979).
No. 78-97. Sears, Roebuck and Co., petitioner, v. Charles W.
Dahm, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certio-
rari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further consideration in light of Chrysler Corporation v.
Brown, 441 U.S. ——— (1979).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. —. Alan J. White, petitioner, v. Office of Personnel Manage-
ment et al. Motion for leave to dispense with printing petition denied.
See Snider v. All State Administrators, Inc., 414 U.S. 685 (1974).

MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1979

Disbarment entered.
No. D-159. In the Matter of Disbarment of Elijah W. Ratcliff.
Disbarment entered.
No. D-162. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Joseph Turner.
It is ordered that John Joseph Turner, of Chicago, Illinois, be sus
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-163. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Phillip Reedy.
It is ordered that James Phillip Reedy, of Chicago, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule isue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-164. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas E. Macurdy.
It is ordered that Thomas E. Macurdy, of Natrona Heights, Penn-
sylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.
No. D–165. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norman Shine Roth-
bart. It is ordered that Norman Shine Rothbart, of Northbrook, Illi-
nois, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-166. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Kaufman. It is
ordered that Robert Kaufman, of New York, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, return-
able within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-167. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur A. Reiser, Jr.
It is ordered that Arthur A. Reiser, Jr., of Western Springs, Illinois,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why
he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

1

MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1979
603
No. D-168. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Lee Powell. It is
ordered that Paul Lee Powell, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 1, Orig. State of Wisconsin et al., plaintiffs, v. State of Illinois
et al;
No. 2, Orig. State of Michigan, plaintiff, v. State of Illinois et al.;
and
No. 3, Orig. State of New York, plaintiff, v. State of Illinois et al.
It is ordered that Honorable Albert B. Maris, Senior Judge of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, is appointed
Special Master in these cases with authority to fix the time and condi-
tions for the filing of additional pleadings and to direct subsequent
proceedings, and with authority to summon witnesses, issue sub-
poenas, and take such evidence as may be introduced and such as he
may deem necessary to call for. The master is directed to submit such
reports as he may deem appropriate.
The master shall allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to him,
the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical as-
sistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion
as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in these
cases becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court.
The motion for leave to file petition for modification of decree is
referred to the Special Master.
No. 78–605. United States et al., petitioners, v. Glen L. Rutherford
et al. Motion of Northwest Academy of Preventive Medicine for leave
to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 78-711. Southeastern Community College, petitioner, v.
Frances B. Davis. Motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a
brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 78–752. T. L. Baker, petitioner, v. Linnie Carl McCollan. Mo-
tion of American Civil Liberties Union et al. for leave to participate
in oral argument, as amici curiae, denied.
No. 78–1475. John W. Pence, petitioner, v. Harold Brown, Sec-
retary of Defense, et al. Application for stay, addressed to Mr.
Justice Brennan and referred to the Court, denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 23, 1979
609
No. 78–793. Philip F. DiLeo, petitioner, v. Board of Regents of
the University of Colorado et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Colorado denied. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
White and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 78-961. Warren Gambino, petitioner, v. Louisiana. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would
grant certiorari and reverse the conviction.
No. 78–1247. Imperial Distributors, Inc., et al., petitioners, v.
Raymond J. Pettine, Judge, United States District Court, District of
Rhode Island. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan,
Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari
and reverse the judgment.
No. 78–6086. Hubert E. Pendleton, petitioner, v. Florida. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida,
Fourth District, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Black-
mun would grant certiorari.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 78-6438. Danny Dean Yost, petitioner, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Director, Florida Department of Offender Rehabilitation. Mo-
tion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas corpus denied.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 78-6296. Remon Bustamante Carlos, petitioner, v. United
States, et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of mandamus
denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 77-1255. James C. Anders, etc., appellant, v. Jesse J. Floyd;
and
No. 78-956. Bernard Jay Coven, petitioner, v. Securities and Ex-
change Commission. Petitions for rehearing denied.
No. 78-5645. Madan Gautam, petitioner, v. First National City
Bank. Motion for leave to file petition for rehearing denied.
ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the term upon the conclusion of the arguments
in the cases listed for hearing this week.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 30, 1979, until
Monday, May 14, 1979.

OPINIONS
No. 77-6431. Abdiel Caban, appellant, v. Kazim Mohammed and
Maria Mohammed. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of New
York for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Stewart. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with
whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 78-3. Curtis Parham, appellant, v. Ellis Franklin Hughes.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Mr.
Justice Stewart announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Rehnquist
and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice White
280-278-79--73

TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1979
618
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice
Blackmun join.
No. 78-354. North Carolina, petitioner, v. Willie Thomas Butler.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Carolina. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring statement by
Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan
with whom Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 77-1439. William Riley Hughes, appellant. e. Oklahoma. Ap-
peal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Oklahoma for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
ORAL ARGUMENT
No. 78-610. Columbus Board of Education et al., petitioners, v.
Gary L. Penick et al. Argued by Mr. Samuel H. Porter for the peti-
tioners, by Mr. Thomas I. Atkins for the respondents, and by Mr.
Drew S. Days, III, for the United States, as amicus curiae, by special
leave of Court.
No. 78-627. Dayton Board of Education et al., petitioners, v. Mark
Brinkman et al. Argued by Mr. David C. Greer for the petitioners, by
Mr. William E. Caldwell for the respondents, and by Mr. Drew S.
Days, III, for the United States, as amicus curiae, by special leave of
Court.
No. 77-1546. William H. Stafford, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. John
Briggs et al. Argued by Mr. Peter Megargee Brown for the petitioners
and by Ms. Doris Peterson for the respondents.
No. 78-303. William E. Colby and Vernon A. Walters, petitioners.
v. Rodney D. Driver et al. Argued by Mr. Earl Harold Nemser for
the petitioners by Mrs. Elinor H. Stillman for the United States, as
amicus curiae, by special leave of Court, and by Mr. Melvin L. Wulf
for the respondents.
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-887. Louisville & Nashville Railroad Company, applicant,
c. John M. Sullivan, Administrator, Federal Railroad Administra-
tion, et al. The document captioned "Application for an order con-
tinuing the injunction granted by a panel of the United States Court
of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit but vacated by that
court en banc, pending the timely filing of a petition for writ of cer-
tiorari and its consideration by this Court" was presented to the Chief
Justice and by him referred to the Court. Treating the papers as an
application for stay, pending the timely filing and disposition of a
280-278-79——74

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 25, 1979
620
petition for writ of certiorari, application denied. Mr. Justice Stevens
would grant the stay.
Adjourned until Monday, April 30, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1979
621
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 78-1223. Maurice Smith et al., petitioners, v. Arkansas State
Highway Employees, Local 1315, et al. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the Court Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion
by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–5885. Herbert G. Wilkins, Sr., petitioner, v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dis-
senting statements by Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this case.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1433. Fredric Chubb, appellant, v. Pennsylvania. Appeal
from the Superior Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The ap-
peal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-5989. Lionel Muse, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of
a substantial federal question.
No. 78-6358. Charles Crane and Faye Crane, appellants, v. Car-
roll County Department of Family and Children Services. Appeal
from the Supreme Court of Georgia. The appeal is dismissed for want
of a substantial federal question.

MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1979
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–582. North Carolina, petitioner, v. Ruben Sonny Connley.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Caro-
lina. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judgment vacated and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of North Carolina for further
consideration in light of North Carolina v. Butler, 441 U.S.—(1979).
No. 78–1051. United States, petitioner, v. Salvatore Finazzo and
Dominic J. Licavoli. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted, judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further consideration in light of Dalia v. United
States, 441 U.S.—(1979).

Petitions for rehearing denied. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the
consideration or decision of these petitions.
ORDERED:
ORDERS
1. That the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Rules 1(a),
3(c), (d) and (e), 4(a), 5(d), 6(d), 7, 10(b), 11(a), (b), (c) and (d)
12, 13(a), 24(b), 27 (b), 28 (g) and (j), 34(a) and (b), 35 (b) and (c),
39 (c) and (d), and 40.
2. That the aforementioned amendments to the Federal Rules of
Appellate Procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1979, and shall
govern all appellate proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar
as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
3. That The Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit to the Congress the aforementioned amendments to the Federal
Rules of Appellate Procedure in accordance with the provisions of
Section 3772 of Title 18, United States Code, and Sections 2072 and
2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
ORDERED:
1. That the Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United States Dis-
trict Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein
Rules 26.2 and 32.1 and amendments to Rules 6(e), 7(c) (2), 9(a),
11(e) (2) and (6), 17(h), 18, 32(c) (3) (E) and 32(f), 35, 40, 41(a),
(b) and (c), and 44 (c).
2. That the aforementioned amendments and additions to the rules
of procedure shall take effect on August 1, 1979, and shall govern all
280-278-79-76

630
MONDAY, APRIL 30, 1979
criminal proceedings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and
practicable, all proceedings then pending.
3. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the aforementioned amendments and additions to the
Rules of Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of
Title 18, United States Code, Sections 3771 and 3772.
ORDERED:
1. That Rule 10 of the Rules Governing Proceedings in the United
States District Courts on application under Section 2254 of Title 28,
United States Code, be, and hereby is, amended.
2. That Rules 10 and 11 of the Rules Governing Proceedings in the
United States District Courts on a motion under Section 2255 of Title
28, United States Code, be, and they hereby are, amended.
3. That the aforementioned amendments to the Rules Governing
Proceedings in the United States District Courts under Section 2254
and Section 2255 of Title 28, United States Code, shall take effect on
August 1, 1979, and shall be applicable to all proceedings then pend-
ing except to the extent that in the opinion of the court their applica-
tion in a particular proceeding would not be feasible or would work
injustice.
4. That the Chief Justice be, and he hereby is, authorized to transmit
the aforementioned amendments to the Rules Governing Section 2254
and Section 2255 Proceedings to the Congress in accordance with the
provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28, United States Code, and Sec-
tions 3771 and 3772 of Title 18, United States Code.
ORDERED:
1. That Rule 410 of the Federal Rules of Evidence be, and it hereby
is, amended:
2. That the aforementioned amendment to the Federal Rules of
Evidence shall take effect on November 1, 1979, and shall be applica-
ble to all proceedings then pending except to the extent that in the
opinion of the court the application of the amended rule in a particular
proceeding would not be feasible or would work injustice.
3. That the Chief Justice be and he hereby is, authorized to trans-
mit to the Congress the aforementioned amendment to the Federal
Rules of Evidence in accordance with the provisions of 28 U.S.C.
§ 2076.

OPINIONS
No. 77-1378. Japan Line, Ltd., et al., appellants, v. County of Los
Angeles et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of California. Judg-
ment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
No. 77-5992. Frank O'Neal Addington, appellant, v. Texas. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Texas. Appeal dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari granted. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Texas for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this case.
No. 77-154. John S. Toll, President, University of Maryland, peti-
tioner, v. Juan Carlos Moreno et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment vacated
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the District
of Maryland for further consideration in light of the Court's opinion
and judgment in Elkins v. Moreno, opinion and judgment of Court of
Appeals of Maryland in Toll v. Moreno, and Board of Regents'
Clarifying Resolution of June 23, 1978. Opinion per curiam announced
by Chief Justice Burger.
Adjourned until Monday, May 14, 1979, at 10 o'clock.
Х

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979
641
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 78–895. Everett Satterfield, appellant, v. Sunny Day Re-
sources, Inc. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wyoming. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–1166. Church of Scientology of California et al., ap-
pellants, v. W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Central District
of California. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr.
Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for
oral argument.
No. 78–1219. David E. Morrill, appellant, v. William J. Jank-
low, Governor of South Dakota. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
South Dakota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial fed-
eral question. Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice
Blackmun would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 78–1393. Fred Cherry, appellant, v. Secretary of the Treas-
ury of the United States. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Southern District of New York. Judgment affirmed.
No. 78–1401. City of Miami, appellant, v. St. Joe Paper Com-
pany et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Florida. The appeal is
dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-1417. Bryan M. Hansen, appellant, v. Minnesota State
Board of Bar Examiners et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of
Minnesota. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
280-278-79-77

642
MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979
No. 78–1508. Skaggs Rudder et al., appellants, v. Wise County
Housing and Redevelopment Authority. Appeal from the Supreme
Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial
federal question.
No. 78-1405. Winthrop Drake Thies, appellant, v. Joint Bar
Association Grievance Committee for the Second and Eleventh Judi-
cial Districts. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New York. Motion
of New York County Lawyers Association for leave to file a brief, as
amicus curiae, granted. The appeal is dismissed for want of a sub-
stantial federal question. Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Powell
would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
No. 78-5441. Eric Stewart Robinson, etc., appellant, v. Patrick A.
Kolstad et al. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. The
appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question. Mr.
Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Stevens would
note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1194. Reeves, Inc., petitioner, v. Tom Kelley et al. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of Hughes v. Oklahoma, 441 U.S. — (1979).
No. 78–1375. United States, petitioner, v. Ronald Santora. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted, judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
consideration in light of Dalia v. United States, 441 U.S. —
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
-
(1979).
No. A-929. Charles Frazier, applicant, v. Robert J. Barbera. Appli-
cation for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to the
Court, denied.
No. A-955. Harold E. Olson, etc., et al., applicants, v. United States.
Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Brennan and referred
to the Court, denied.
No. D-160. In the Matter of Disbarment of Aaron R. Fodiman.
Aaron R. Fodiman, of Arlington, Virginia, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
0
2

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979
643
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar
of this Court. The rule to show cause, heretofore issued on February
26, 1979, is hereby discharged.
No. D-161. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bong Hyun Kim. Bong
Hyun Kim, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The rule to show cause, heretofore issued on February 26, 1979,
is hereby discharged.
No. D-168. In the matter of Disbarment of Paul Lee Powell. Paul
Lee Powell, of Chicago, Illinois, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The rule to show cause, heretofore issued on April 23, 1979, is
hereby discharged.
No. 81 Orig. Commonwealth of Kentucky, plaintiff, v. State of
Indiana, et al. It is ordered that the Honorable Robert Van Pelt,
Senior Judge of the United States District Court for the District
of Nebraska, is appointed Special Master in this case with authority
to fix the time and conditions for the filing of additional pleadings
and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with authority to summon
witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence as may be intro-
duced and such as he may deem necessary to call for. The master is
directed to submit such reports as he may deem appropriate.
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper ex-
penses shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such
proportion as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court. Motion of Public Serv-
ice Company of Indiana, Inc. for leave to intervene referred to the
Special Master.
No. 77–1546. William H. Stafford, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. John
Briggs et al.; and
No. 78-303. William E. Colby and Vernon A. Walters, petitioners,
v. Rodney D. Driver et al. These cases restored to the calendar for
reargument. Mr. Justice Marshall dissents. Mr. Justice White took no
part in the consideration or decision of these orders.

644
MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 78-1201. Mobil Oil Corporation, appellant, v. Commissioner
of Taxes of Vermont. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Vermont.
Motion of Committee on State Taxation of The Council of State
Chambers of Commerce for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae,
granted. Motion of the National Association of Manufacturers for
leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted. In this case probable
jurisdiction noted. Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of this appeal.

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979
هم.
OPINIONS
No. 77–926. Geraldine G. Cannon, petitioner, v. University of Chi-
cago et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Chief
Justice Burger concurs in the judgment. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice White with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joins.
Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 77-719. Jerome D. Chapman, Commissioner of the Texas
Department of Human Resources, et al., petitioners, v. Houston Wel-
fare Rights Organization et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit; and
No. 77-5324. Julia Gonzalez, etc., petitioner, v. James F. Young,
Director, Hudson County Welfare Board, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judg-
ment in No. 77-719 reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Judgment in No. 77-5324 affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Opinion by Mr.
Justice White concurring in judgment. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall join in part.
No. 77-1829. Griffin B. Bell et al., petitioners, v. Louis Wolfish et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins.
No. 78-488. United States, petitioner, v. 564.54 Acres of Land, more
or less, situated in Monroe and Pike Counties, Pennsylvania, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Concurring opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice White. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 77-1806. Ford Motor Company, etc., petitioner, v. National
Labor Relations Board et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States

MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979
673
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the result.
No. 77-1724. Harry G. Burks, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Howard M.
Lasker et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Con-
curring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart concurring in the judgment, with whom Mr. Justice Powell
joins. Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, May 21, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 21, 1979
675
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice.
White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
Mr. Justice Brennan said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by Mr. Justice
Brennan, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 78-1013. Peggy J. Connor et al., petitioners, v. J. P. Coleman,
Judge, United States Court of Appeals, et al. On petition for writ of
mandamus. Petition for writ of mandamus denied. Opinion peri
curiam. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of this petition.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1314. Richard E. Spencer, appellant, v. Lorraine B. Spen-
cer. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of North Carolina. The appeal
is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari is
denied.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-946. J. C. Benefield, applicant, v. Florida. Application to
continue stay of mandate of the Supreme Court of Florida, addressed
to Mr. Justice Marshall and referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-957. John E. Behnke, applicant, v. Committee on Profes-
sional Ethics and Conduct of Iowa State Bar Association. Application
for stay of disciplinary sentence, presented to Mr. Justice Blackmun
and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Blackmun would
grant the application.
No. A-970. Donald D. Haynie, applicant, v. United States. Appli-
cation for bail pending appeal, presented to the Chief Justice and by
him referred to the Court, denied.
No. A-995. Donald M. Gomes, applicant, v. Rhode Island Inter-
scholastic League et al. Application to vacate stay entered by the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, presented to
Mr. Justice Brennan and by him referred to the Court, denied.
280-278-79— -80

676
MONDAY, MAY 21, 1979
No. D-137. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ira Stuart Gilbert. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-156. In the Matter of Disbarment of Eugene A. Falk. Dis-
barment entered.
No. D-163. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Phillip Reedy.
James Phillip Reedy, of Pompano Beach, Florida, having requested to
resign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the
Bar of this Court. The rule to show cause, heretofore issued on April
23, 1979, is hereby discharged.
No. 78, Original. State of California, plaintiff, v. State of Arizona
and the United States. It is ordered that Honorable Roy W. Harper,
Senior Judge for the United States District Court for the Eastern and
Western Districts of Missouri, is appointed Special Master in this case
with authority to fix the time and conditions for the filing of addi-
tional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with
authority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence
as may be introduced and such as he may deem necessary to call for.
The master is directed to submit such reports as he may deem
appropriate.
The master shall be allowed his actual expenses. The allowances to
him, the compensation paid to his technical, stenographic and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper expenses
shall be charged against and be borne by the parties in such proportion
as the Court may hereafter direct.
It is further ordered that if the position of Special Master in this
case becomes vacant during a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice
shall have authority to make a new designation which shall have the
same effect as if originally made by the Court.
No. 77-1511. Joseph A. Califano. Jr., Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion and Welfare, petitioner, v. Evelyn Elliott et al. Motion for leave
to substitute Nancy Yamasaki in place of Evelyn Elliott, deceased, as
a party respondent granted.
No. 78–1155. Joseph Vitek, etc., et al., appellants, v. Larry D.
Jones. Motion for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered
that Thomas A. Wurtz, Esquire, of Lincoln, Nebraska, is appointed to
serve as counsel for appellee in this case.
No. 78–6620. Harry Cardillo. petitioner, v. United States Parole
Commission et al. Application for release from custody, addressed to
Mr. Justice Stewart and referred to the Court, denied.

shall.
LEAVE TO FILE PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 78–6595. George W. Nicholas, petitioner, v. C. E. Fenton,
Warden, et al. Motion for leave to file petition for writ of habeas cor-
pus denied.

The Court will take a recess from today until Tuesday, May 29, 1979.

OPINIONS
No. 78-744. United States, petitioner, v. Charles Timmreck. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-561. United States, petitioner, v. Neil T. Naftalin. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78–275. Oscar Mayer & Co., et al., petitioners, v. Joseph W.
Evans. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the

694
MONDAY, MAY 21, 1979
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens
concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Chief Justice
Burger, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
No. 78-749. Kentucky, petitioner, v. Harold Whorton. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam announced by Mr. Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice
Marshall join.
Adjourned until Tuesday, May 29, 1979, at 10 o'clock.
☑

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, MAY 24, 1979
695
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1016. John A. Spinkelink, applicant v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Offender Rehabilitation,
et al. Application for stay of execution, presented to Mr. Justice
Marshall and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the application for a stay
of execution. Furthermore, they object because the Court announces
its action without first affording them an opportunity to prepare,
circulate and file a statement in support of their view.
No. A-1020. Louie L. Wainwright, Secretary, Florida Department
of Offender Rehabilitation, et al. applicants, v. John A. Spinkelink.
Motion of the Attorney General of Florida to vacate the order entered
by Hon. Elbert Parr Tuttle, Senior Judge of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on May 22, 1979, denied. Mr. Justice
Rehnquist reserves the right to file a written statement at a future.
date.
No. A-1017. Dolley M. E. Filartiga et al. applicants, v. America
Norberto Pena-Irala et al. Application for stay of deportation, pre-
sented to Mr. Justice Marshall and by him referred to the Court,
denied.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, MAY 25, 1979
697
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-1025. John A. Spenkelink, applicant, v. Louie L. Wain-
wright, Secretary, Florida Department of Offender Rehabilitation,
et al. Application for stay of execution, presented to Mr. Justice
Powell and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Bren-
nan and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the stay. Mr. Justice Black-
mun took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.

280-278-79--83



(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1979
699
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINIONS PER CURIAM
No. 78-1060. Great Western Sugar Co., petitioner, v. Edward L.
Nelson. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted, judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Ap-
peals with directions to vacate the United States District Court for
the District of Colorado's judgment and to remand the case for dis-
missal of respondent's complaint. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens.
No. 78-5944. Roosevelt Green, Jr., petitioner, v. Georgia. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. Motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted, sentence vacated, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Georgia for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting statement by
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1516. Pierre J. Wessel, appellant, v. Pennsylvania State
Board of Law Examiners. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Penn-
sylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of a
substantial federal question.
No. 78–1523. James Eugene Floyd, Jr., appellant, v. Texas. Ap-
peal from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78–1521. Alan B. Epstein et al., appellants, v. Adler, Barish,
Daniels, Levin & Creskoff. Appeal from the Supreme Court of Penn-
sylvania, Eastern District. The appeal is dismissed for want of
280-278-79
-84

700
TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1979
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6238. Ainsworth C. Jackson, appellant, v. T. C. Martin,
Warden. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treat-
ing the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–6405. Millicent Linden, appellant, v. Dial Press and Olga
Ley. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating
the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of
certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6474. Nancy Murray, appellant, v. New Hampshire et al.
Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.
The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-6547. Betty Minyard Stein, appellant, v. William Andress,
Jr., et al. Appeal from the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Fifth
Supreme Judicial District. The appeal is dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–1553. James P. Beggans, Jr., appellant, v. Public Funds
for Public Schools of New Jersey et al.; and
No. 78-1556. Brendan T. Byrne et al., appellants, v. Public Funds
for Public Schools of New Jersey et al. Appeals from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
The Chief Justice. Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist
would note probable jurisdiction and set the cases for oral argument.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1. Chrysler Corporation, petitioner, v. Clement Gabriele.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Oscar Mayer & Co. v. Evans, 441 U.S. — (1979).
-
No. 78–53. Whirlpool Corporation. petitioner, v. Lewis Simpson.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari is
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Oscar Mayer & Co. v. Evans, 441 U.S. — (1979).
-

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1979
701
No. 78-419. Jos. Schlitz Brewing Co., petitioner, v. Robert E.
Smith. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consideration in
light of Oscar Mayer & Co. v. Evans, 441 U.S. — (1979).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-169. In Matter of Disbarment of Donald S. Carnow. It is
ordered that Donald S. Carnow of Chicago, Illinois be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 82 Orig. New Mexico v. Texas. The Solicitor General is in-
vited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.

OPINIONS
Wade H.
McCree, Jr.
No. 78–99. Harry Parker. petitioner, v. James Randolph et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Mr. Justice Rehnquist announced the

TUESDAY, MAY 29, 1979
717
judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion with respect to Parts
I and III and an opinion with respect to Part II in which Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice White join. Mr.
Justice Blackmun filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring
in judgment. Mr. Justice Stevens filed a dissenting opinion in which
Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall join. Mr. Justice Powell
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-38. International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers et al.,
= petitioners, v. Leroy Foust. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed insofar
as it upheld the award of punitive damages and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Blackmun concurring in the result with whom Mr. Chief
Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 78-201. John B. Greenholtz, etc., et al., petitioners, v. Inmates
of the Nebraska Penal and Correctional Complex et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr.
Justice Stevens join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 4, 1979, at 10 o'clock.
Х



(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1979
719
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Jus-
tice Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-1396. Louis Charbonnet, III, et al., appellants, v. Henry
Braden, IV, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Louisiana. Judgment affirmed. Mr. Justice
Brennan would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
No. 78-6486. Leon Douglas Alexander, appellant, v. W. J. Estelle,
Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Appeal from the
Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal dismissed for want
of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as
a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6646. Hajji A. R. Ahmad, appellant, v. Michael Rodak,
Jr., Clerk, Supreme Court of the United States. Appeal from the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
The appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, cer-
tiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 78-750. Kentucky, petitioner, v. Ralph Brannon. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky. The motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. The
petition for a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for further considera-
tion in light of Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S. — (1979).
-
No. 78-1084. Kentucky, petitioner, v. Barry Vaughn Williams.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for
further consideration in light of Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S.
(1979).
280-278-79-86
-

720
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1979
No. 78–1085. Kentucky, petitioner, v. James Ronald Avery. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for
further consideration in light of Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S. –
(1979).
No. 78–1493. Kentucky, petitioner, v. Edgar Gilbert Miller. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for
further consideration in light of Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S. —
(1979).
-
No. 78–1643. William Lombard, etc., petitioner, v. Joseph Marcera
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for a writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in
light of Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. (1979). Mr. Justice Marshall
dissents.
---
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
A-958. Jasper F. Williams et al., applicants, v. David Zbaraz et al.
Application for stay, addressed to Mr. Justice Rehnquist and referred
to the Court, denied.
A-1012. Leonard J. LaMagna, applicant, v. United States. Ap-
plication for writ of habeas corpus and for bail, presented to Mr. Jus-
tice Marshall and by him referred to the Court, denied.
No. 78-1453. United States et al., petitioners, v. Harvey F. Euge.
The motion for appointment of counsel granted and it is ordered that
James W. Erwin, Esquire, of St. Louis, Missouri, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the respondent in this case provided he apply for admis-
sion to the Bar of this Court prior to the commencement of the next
Term of Court.
No. 78-1538. John D. Callahan et al., petitioners, v. Charles E.
Kimball et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this
case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 78-1545. Anne B. Zipes et al., petitioners, v. Trans World Air-
lines, Inc.; and
No. 78-1549. Trans World Airlines, Inc., petitioner, v. Anne B.
Zipes et al. The joint motions to defer consideration of the petitions
for writs of certiorari granted. Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in
the consideration or decision of these motions.

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1979
721
No. 78–1577. Sears, Roebuck & Co., petitioner, v. County of Los
Angeles and City of Compton. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States. Mr.
Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of this
order.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 78-1548. California Brewers Association et al., petitioners, v.
Abram Bryant. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Mr. Justice Stevens
took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 78-6020. Michael M. Busic, petitioner, v. United States; and
No. 78-6029. Anthony LaRocca, Jr., petitioner, v. United States;
Motions of petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and a total
of one and one half hours are allotted for oral argument.

The Court will take a recess from Tuesday, June 5, 1979 until
Monday, June 11, 1979.

MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1979
OPINIONS
735
No. 77-1554. County Court of Ulster County, New York et al.,
petitioners, v. Samuel Allen et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice
Stevens. Concurring opinioin by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Powell with whom Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr.
Justice Stewart, and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 78–156. United States, petitioner, v. Hugh J. Addonizio et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Third Circuit. Judgments reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 78-647. Karen Marchioro et al., appellants, v. Neale V. Chaney
et al. On appeal from the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice Powell took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-58. G. Gavin Brown III, petitioner, v. Mark Paul Felsen.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
No. 77–6949. Robert Dunn, petitioner, v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-776. United States, petitioner, v. Milton Dean Batchelder.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Adjourned until tommorrow at 10 o'clock

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JUNE 5, 1979
1737
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice.
Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice Stevens.
OPINIONS
No. 78–225. Bruce Babbitt, Governor of the State of Arizona, et al.,
appellants, v. United Workers National Union, etc., et al. On appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of Arizona.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the District of Arizona for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Mr. Justice Marshall joins.
No. 78–233. Personnel Administrator of Massachusetts, et al., ap-
pellants, v. Helen B. Feeney. On appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Massachusetts. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the District of
Massachusetts for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion
by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom Mr. Justice White joins. Dissenting
opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan
joins.
No. 78-5066. Irvin Jerome Dunaway, petitioner, v. New York. On
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, Fourth Judicial Department. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New York,
Fourth Judicial Department for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
Opinion by Mr. Justice White concurring in the judgment and opinion.
Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Mr. Justice Rehnquist with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 78-5072. Shirley Davis, petitioner, v. Otto E. Passman. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings on conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Chief
Justice Burger with whom Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehn-
280-278-79--87

738
TUESDAY, JUNE 5, 1979
quist join. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart with whom
Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
Ajourned until Monday, June 11, 1979 at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1979
739
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice
Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–1482. Elmer L. Meyers, appellant, v. Clayton Chilcote.
Appeal from the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton County. The
appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers.
whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari,
certiorari denied.
No. 78-1590. Grover Jones, Jr., appellant, v. Committee of
Legal Ethics of the West Virginia State Bar. Appeal from the Su-
preme Court of Appeals of West Virginia. The appeal dismissed for
want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6553. Eileen B. Cohen Lupert, appellant, v. College of Law
of Syracuse University. Appeal from the Court of Appeals of New
York. The appeal dismissed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the
papers whereon the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certio-
rari, certiorari denied.
No. 78-6581. Nancy Jewell Cross, appellant, v. Marvin Church,
County Clerk-Recorder of San Mateo County, et al. Appeal from the
Supreme Court of California. The appeal dismissed for want of juris-
diction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 77-6855. Bobby Hardwick, petitioner, v. Mamie Reese, etc. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for

MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1979
the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Greenholtz v.
Inmates of Nebraska Penal Complex, 442 U.S.
-
(1979).
No. 78–950. Missouri Board of Probation and Parole, etc., et al.,
petitioners, v. James E. Williams et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Motion of respondent Williams for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Greenholtz v. Inmates of
Nebraska Penal Complex, 442 U.S. — (1979).
No. 78–1282. Bill Williams et al., petitioners, v. Jimmy Louis
Phillips. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Oklahoma. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Oklahoma for
further consideration in light of Greenholtz v. Inmates of Nebraska
Penal Complex, 442 U.S. (1979).
-
No. 78–1533. Connecticut Board of Pardons et al., petitioners, v.
David Dumschat et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motion of respondents
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further considera-
tion in light of Greenholtz v. Inmates of Nebraska Penal Complex,
442 U.S. (1979).
-
No. 78–5419. George D. Van Curen, petitioner, v. Arnold R. Jago,
Superintendent, Southern Ohio Correctional Facility. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Greenholtz v. Inmates of Nebraska
Penal Complex, 442 U.S.- (1979).
No. 78-5551. Henry Albert Smith, petitioner, v. James C. Wood-
ard et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of Green-
holtz v. Inmates of Nebraska Penal Complex, 442 U.S. (1979).

MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1979
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
741
No. A-1042. Douglas Rega, applicant, v. William Curios, Jr., Com-
missioner of New York City Department of Correction. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence, presented to Mr. Justice Mar-
shall and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice Brennan.
and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant the application.
No. D-158. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold C. Herman.
Disbarment entered.
No. 78–432. United Steelworkers of America, AFL-CIO-CLC,
petitioner, v. Brian F. Weber et al.;
No. 78-435. Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation, petitioner,
v. Brian F. Weber et al.; and
No. 78-436. United States et al., petitioners, v. Brian F. Weber
et al. The motion of Rudy Gordon et al. for leave to intervene and
for an order vacating the judgment below and remanding the cases
for a new trial with intervenors as party defendants denied. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration
or decision of this motion.
No. 78–1143. Cyrus Vance, Secretary of State of the United States,
appellant, v. Laurence J. Terrazas. The motion of the Solicitor General
to dispense with printing the appendix granted.
No. 78-1202. Vincent F. Chiarella, petitioner, v. United States.
The motion of the petitioner to dispense with printing the appendix
granted.
No. 78-1604. Central Machinery Company, appellant, v. Arizona
State Tax Commission. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief
in this case expressing the views of the United States.
APPEALS JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 78-1369. Committee for Public Education and Religious Lib-
erty, et al., appellants, v. Edward V. Regan, etc., et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.
In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
No. 78-1588. Carol Vance et al., appellants, v. Universal Amuse-
ment Co., Inc., et al. Appeal from the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. In this case probable jurisdiction noted.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
