OPINIONS
761
No. 78-575. Southern Railway Company, petitioner, v. Seaboard
Allied Milling Corp., et al.;
No. 78–597. Interstate Commerce Commission, petitioner, v. Sea-
board Allied Milling Corp., et al.; and
No. 78-604. Seaboard Coast Line Railroad Company, et al., peti-
tioners, v. Seaboard Allied Milling Corp., et al. On writs of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Stevens. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the considera-
tion or decision of these cases.
No. 78-6. Hilmar G. Moore, et al., appellants, v. John Pleasant
Sims, et al. On appeal from the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Texas. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas
with instructions that the complaint be dismissed. Opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice Rehnquist. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens with whom
Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
No. 78-711. Southeastern Community College, petitioner, v.
Frances B. Davis. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.

762
MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1979
No. 78-753. Great American Federal Savings & Loan Association,
et al., petitioners, v. John R. Novotny. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Justice Stewart. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Concur-
ring opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Jus-
tice White with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall
join.
No. 78-625. Cecil D. Andrus, Secretary of the Interior, et al., pe-
titioners, v. Sierra Club, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed and case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Mr. Justice Brennan.
No. 78–511. Lo-Ji Sales, Inc., petitioner, v. New York. On writ
of certiorari to the Appellate Term, Supreme Court of New York,
Ninth and Tenth Judicial Districts. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Appellate Term, Supreme Court of New York, Ninth
and Tenth Judicial Districts, for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
No. 78–690. Kathleen R. Reiter, petitioner, v. Sonotone Corpora-
tion, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concur-
ring opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist. Mr. Justice Brennan took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Monday, June 18, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1979
763
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78-931. Bruce Babbitt, Governor of the State of Arizona,
et al., appellants, v. United Farm Workers National Union, etc., et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Ari-
zona. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the United States Dis-
trict Court for the District of Arizona for further consideration in
light of Babbitt v. United Farm Workers, 442 U.S.—(1979).
No. 78-1527. Juan F. Luna a/b/o Isamelina Luna Gonzalez, ap-
pellant, v. Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Appeal from
the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
the appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari
denied.
No. 78-6409. James Howard Bello, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The appeal is dis-
missed for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the
appeal was taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
No. 78–1546. Montana Contractors' Association et al., appellants,
v. Juanita M. Kreps, Secretary of Commerce of the United States, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Montana. The appeal is dismissed for want of jurisdiction.
No. 78-1626. Jean Rosenbaum, appellant, v. Kurt Rosenbaum. Ap-
peal from the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. The appeal
is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.
No. 78-1684. Thomas M. Fahey, dba Castle Rest Nursing Home,
appellant, v. Charles J. Hynes, etc. Appeal from the Appellate Divi-
sion of the Supreme Court of New York, Fourth Judicial Depart-
ment. The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal
question.
280-278-79- 90

704
MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1979
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–5693. Daniel Ross, petitioner, v. Kaye Byrd, etc., et al. On.
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further con--
sideration in light of Greenholtz v. Inmates of the Nebraska Penal and
Correctional Complex et al., 442 U.S. 1 (1979). Mr. Justice Stewart,
Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens
dissent.
No. 78–6095. Larry Griffith, petitioner, v. Arizona. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of cetiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Su-
preme Court of Arizona for further consideration in light of Green-
holtz v. Inmates of Nebraska Penal and Correctional Complex et al.,
442 U.S. 1 (1979). Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr.
Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens dissent.
No. 78–6232. Ray L. White, petitioner, v. Arizona. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arizona. Motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Arizona for further consideration in light of Green-
holtz v. Inmates of the Nebraska Penal and Correctional Complex et
al., 442 U.S. 1 (1979). Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Blackmun,
Mr. Justice Rehnquist and Mr. Justice Stevens dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-1026. University of Tennessee et al., applicants v. Rita
Sanders Geier et al., and
No. A-1051. Tennessee Higher Education Commission, applicant,
v. Rita Sanders Geier et al. Applications for stay, presented to Mr.
Justice Stewart and by him referred to the Court, denied. Mr. Justice
Marshall took no part in the consideration or decision of these
applications.
No. A-1067. Aaron E. Henry et al., applicants v. Mississippi. Ap-
plication for stay or in the alternative for advancement of the appeal,
presented to the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court,
denied.
No. D-166. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Kaufman.
Disbarment entered.
No. 27, Original. State of Ohio, plaintiff, v. Commonwealth of
Kentucky; and

MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1979
765
No. 67, Original. State of Idaho, ex rel. John V. Evans, Governor;
David H. LeRoy, Attorney General; Joseph C. Greenley, Director,
Department of Fish and Game, plaintiff, v. States of Oregon and
Washington. Exceptions to the Reports of the Special Masters set for
oral argument in due course.
No. 83, Original. State of Maryland, et al., plaintiffs, v. State of
Louisiana; and
No. 84, Original. United States of America, plaintiff, v. State of
Alaska. Motions for leave to file bills of complaint granted and de-
fendants shall have 60 days to answer.
No. 77-1724. Harry G. Burks, Jr., et al., petitioners, v. Howard M.
Lasker et al. Motion of respondents to be relieved of costs denied. Mr.
Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 78–253. Nolan Estes et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of Dallas NAACP et al;
No. 78–282. Donald E. Curry et al., petitioners, v. Metropolitan
Branches of the Dallas NAACP, et al.; and
No. 78–283. Ralph F. Brinegar et al., petitioners, v. Metropolian
Branches of the Dallas NAACP et al. Motion of Dallas Alliance et al.,
for leave to file a brief, as amici curiae, granted. Motion of petitioners,
Brinegar, et al., for additional time for oral argument granted and
fifteen additional minutes are allotted for that purpose. Respondents
allotted fifteen additional minutes for oral argument. Mr. Justice Mar-
shall took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions.
No. 78–630. Washington et al., appellants, v. Confederated Tribes
of the Colville Indian Reservation et al. Motion of Solicitor General
for additional time for oral argument granted and fifteen additional
minutes are allotted to the appellees. Appellants allotted fifteen addi-
tional minutes for oral argument.
No. 78-857. National Labor Relations Board, petitioner, v. Yeshiva
University; and
No. 78-997. Yeshiva University Faculty Association, petitioner,
v. Yeshiva University. Motion of Solicitor General for divided argu-
ment granted.
No. 78-911. Industrial Union Department, AFL-CIO, petitioner,
v. American Petroleum Institute et al.; and
No. 78-1036. Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, petitioner, v.
American Petroleum Institute et al. Motion of Solicitor General for
additional time for oral argument granted and fifteen additional min-
utes are allotted to petitioners. Respondents allotted fifteen additional
minutes for oral argument.

766
MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1979
No. 78–952. Randal Rush et al., appellants, v. Jeffrey D. Savchuk.
Motion of New York State Trial Lawyers Association for leave to file
a brief, as amicus curiae, denied.
No. 78-1183. Carbon Fuel Company, petitioner, v. United Mine
Workers of America et al. Motion of the Chamber of Commerce of
the United States for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
Motion of The Washington Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief,
as amicus curiae, granted. Motion of Bituminous Coal Operators'
Association, Inc. for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 78–1418. William E. Bloomer, Jr., petitioner, v. Liberty Mu-
tual Insurance Company, etc. Motion of petitioner to dispense with
printing the appendix granted.
No. 78–1653. North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission et al.,
petitioners, v. Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians. Solicitor General
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 78–5705. Otis Trammel, Jr., petitioner, v. United States. Mo-
tion of Michigan Bar Association Standing Committee on Civil Pro-
cedure for leave to file a brief, as amicus curiae, granted.
No. 78–6386. William James Rummel, petitioner, v. W. J. Estelle,
Jr., Director, Texas Department of Corrections. Motion for appoint-
ment of counsel granted and it is ordered that Scott J. Atlas, Esq.,
of Houston, Texas, is appointed to serve as counsel for petitioner in
this case.

No. 78-685. Aberdeen and Rockfish Railroad Company, et al.,
petitioners, v. United States et al. Motion of PPG Industries for leave
to intervene denied. Motion of Fort Howard Paper Company for
leave to intervene denied. Motion of Allied Chemical Corp. et al. for
leave to intervene denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied.
Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of
these motions and petition.
No. 78–1399. Chicago-Midwest Meat Association, petitioner, v.
City of Evanston, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan and Mr. Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 78–1454. Novella T. Trageser, petitioner, v. Libbie Rehabili-
tation Center, Inc., etc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice
Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.
No. 78–1470. Mary Francis Lopez, petitioner, v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied. Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Mar-
shall would grant certiorari.
No. 78–1688. City Council of the City of Philadelphia, et al.,
petitioners, v. Resident Advisory Board of Philadelphia, et al. Mo-
tion of respondent Nellie Reynolds, for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit denied.
No. 78–6699. Terry Lee Goodwin, petitioner, v. Joe S. Hopper,
Warden. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Georgia denied. Dissenting statement by Mr. Justice Brennan and
Mr. Justice Marshall.

No. 78–6748. Peter Fried, petitioner, v. Warden, New York State
Correctional Facility at Elmira, et al. Motion for leave to file petition
for writ of habeas corpus denied.

OPINIONS
No. 78-309. Touche Ross Co., petitioner, v. Edward S. Redington,
etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquit. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Marshall. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or
decision of this case.
No. 78-17. United Gas Pipe Line Company, petitioner, v. Billy J.
McCombs et al.; and
No. 78–249. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, petitioner, v.
Billy J. McCombs et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases

782
MONDAY, JUNE 18, 1979
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conform-
ity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the consideration or decision of
these cases.
No. 78-605. United States et al., petitioners, v. Glen L. Rutherford
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall.
No. 78–5384. David Sandstrom, petitioner, v. Montana. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Montana. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Montana for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Brennan. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Rehnquist
with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins.
No. 77–1609. Terry Terrol Torres, appellant, v. Puerto Rico. Ap-
peal from the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in
the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall
and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.
No. 78–349. United States, petitioner, v. Henry Helstoski. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens concuring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Mr. Justice Stewart joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 78–546. Henry Helstoski, petitioner, v. H. Curtis Meanor,
United States District Judge, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Dissenting opinion by Mr.
Justice Brennan. Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
Adjourned until Wednesday, June 20, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

OPINIONS
No. 77-1497. Arkansas, petitioner, v. Lonnie James Sanders. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Arkansas. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Powell. Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice
Burger concurring in the judgment with whom Mr. Justice Stevens
joins. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun with whom Mr.
Justice Rehnquist joins.
No. 78–223. National Labor Relations Board et al., petitioners, v.
Baptist Hospital, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part and,
vacated in part and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Mr. Justice Powell. Concurring opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in the judgment with
whom Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall join.
No. 77-1511. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Educa
tion, and Welfare, petitioner, v. Nancy Yamasaki et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals for further procedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Mr. Justice.
Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 78-334. Kenneth F. Fare, etc., petitioner, v. Michael C. On writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Judgment reversed
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of California for further
proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Marshall
with whom Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Stevens join. Dis-
senting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell.
No. 78-5374. Michael Lee Smith, petitioner, v. Maryland. On writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Dissenting opinion by

784
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 20, 1979
Mr. Justice Marshall with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins. Mr. Jus-
tice Powell took no part in the consideration of this case.
No. 78–160. Roy Tibbals Wilson et al., petitioners, v. Omaha Indian
Tribe et al.; and
No. 78–161. Iowa et al., petitioners, v. Omaha Indian Tribe et al.
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Mr. Justice White. Concurring opinion by Mr.
Justice Blackmun with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger joins. Mr.
Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of these
cases.
No. 75–1690. James Parham, Individually and as Commissioner of
Department of Human Resources, et al., appellants, v. J. L. and J. R.,
minors, etc. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Georgia. Judgment reversed and case remanded to
the United States District Court for the Middle District of Georgia
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart
concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concur
ring in part and dissenting in part with whom Mr. Justice Marshall
and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
No. 77-1715. Secretary of Public Welfare of Pennsylvania et al.,
appellants, v. Institutionalized Juveniles et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Mr.
Chief Justice Burger. Mr. Justice Stewart concurs in the judgment
for reasons stated in his concurring opinion in Parham v. J. L., ante.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan concurring in part and dissenting in
part with whom Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Stevens join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 25, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1979
785
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice
Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Black-
mun, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, and Mr. Justice
Stevens.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 76-6718. Roy Kirk French, III, appellant, v. A. Eugene Black-
burn. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Middle
District of North Carolina. Judgment affirmed.
No. 78-449. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion, and Welfare, appellant, v. Cathy Ann Stevens et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.
Judgment affirmed. Califano v. Westcott, 443 U.S.
_
(1979).
No. 78-603. Joseph A. Califano, Jr., Secretary of Health, Educa-
tion, and Welfare, appellant, v. Mary Browne et al. Appeal from the
United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
Motion of appellee Mary Browne for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is granted. Judgment affirmed. Califano v. Westcott, 443 U.S.
(1979).
No. 78-1614. School District of Pittsburgh, appellant, v. Pennsyl-
vania Department of Education et al.; and
No. 78–1620. Pequea Valley School District, appellant, v. Penn-
sylvania Department of Education et al. Appeals from the Supreme
Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District. The appeals are dismissed
for want of a substantial federal question. Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr.
Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Stevens would note probable jurisdic-
tion and set cases for oral argument.
No. 78–1638. H. Lynn Womack, appellant, v. City of Norfolk.
Appeal from the Supreme Court of Virginia. The appeal is dismissed
for want of jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was
taken as a petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied. Mr. Justice
Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall would treat
appeal as a petition for certiorari, as does the Court, would grant cer-
tiorari and reverse the conviction.
280-278-79- -93

786
MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1979
No. 78–5373. Weegail Washington, appellant, v. Texas. Appeal
from the County Court at Law Number One, Travis County, Texas.
Motion of appellant for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the County Court at Law
Number One, Travis County, Texas, for further consideration in light
of Brown v. Texas, 443 U.S. (1979).
No. 78-5658. Leonard Willie, appellant, v. Louisiana. Appeal from
the Supreme Court of Louisiana. The appeal is dismissed for want of
jurisdiction. Treating the papers whereon the appeal was taken as a
petition for writ of certiorari, certiorari denied.
CERTIORARI SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 78–162. RGP, Inc., et al., petitioners, v. Omaha Indian Tribe
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther consideration in light of Wilson v. Omaha Indian Tribe, 442 U.S.
(1979).
No. 78-567. Jeffrey Richard Robbins, petitioner, v. California. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California,
First Appellate District, for further consideration in light of Arkan-
sas v. Sanders, 442 U.S. (1979).
No. 78–600. Donald E. Percy, Secretary, Wisconsin Department of
Health and Social Services, petitioner, v. Ronald Francis Terry, aka
Barbara Lynn Terry. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Wisconsin. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for fur-
ther consideration in light of Parham v. J. L. and J. R., 442 U.S.-
1979), and Greenholtz v. Inmates of Nebraska Penal Complex, 442
U.S. 1 (1979).
No. 78–1136. California, petitioner, v. Patrick Steven W. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Sec-
ond Appellate District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Second Appellate District, for further consideration in light
of Fare v. Michael C., 442 U.S. (1979).
No. 78–1273. National Jewish Hospital and Research Center, pe-
tition, v. National Labor Relations Board. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Cir-
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and

MONDAY, JUNE 25, 1979
787
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in
light of National Labor Relations Board v. Baptist Hospital, Inc.,
442 U.S.
-
(1979).
No. 78–1398. Joel Shiffrin et al., petitioners, v. Earl Bratton et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further consideration in light of Touche Ross & Co. v. Redington,
442 U.S. (1979).
No. 78-5617. Duncan Peder McKenzie, Jr., petitioner, v. Montana.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Montana.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Montana for further consideration
in light of Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. ——— (1979).
No. 78-6179. Robert Whisenhunt, petitioner, v. Georgia. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Georgia. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals of Georgia for further consideration in light of
Sandstrom v. Montana, 442 U.S. (1979) and County Court of
Ulster County, New York v. Allen, 442 U.S. — — (1979).

Massachusetts. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

part with whom Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Stewart and
Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.

part and case remanded to the United States District Court for the

Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

serve System, petitioner, v. David R. Merrill. On writ of certiorari to

Circuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals

writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Opinion
by Mr. Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment with whom Mr.
Chief Justice Burger and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join. Mr. Justice

Mr. Justice Stewart said:
"I am authorized to say that the Court will sit next Monday to
announce all the remaining opinions now scheduled to be announced
during the present Term."
Adjourned until Monday, July 2, 1979, at 10 o'clock.

OPINION PER CURIAM

Sprecher, Judge, United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh

forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion per curiam.

The appeal is dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

MONDAY, JULY 2, 1979
ing in No. 78-627, post. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Powell in

No. 77-1301. Gannett Co., Inc., petitioner, v. Daniel A. DePas-
quale, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of New
York. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart. Concurring
opinion by Mr. Chief Justice Burger. Concurring opinion by Mr. Jus-

Marshall join.
No. 77-983. Washington et al., petitioners, v. Washington State
Commercial Passenger Fishing Vessel Association et al.; Washington
et al., petitioners, v. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington; and
No. 78–119. Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et al.;
Washington et al., petitioners, v. United States et al.; and
No. 78–139. Puget Sound Gillnetters Association et al., petition-
ers, v. United States District Court for the Western District of Wash-
ington (United States et al., real parties in interest). On writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgments in No. 77-983 vacated and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Washington for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. In No. 78–119, judgment as to International
Fishery case affirmed, and judgment as to Washington Fishery case
vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Judgment in
No. 78–139 vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Mr. Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice
Powell with whom Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist join.
The Chief Justice said:
"All cases submitted, and all other matters before the Court which
were ready for disposition, have been acted on by the Court. It is

MONDAY, JULY 2, 1979
807
therefore ordered that all cases remaining on the docket but not ready
for consideration are hereby continued to the session of the Court be-
ginning the first Monday in October.
"Accordingly, the Court is adjourned to the first Monday in Octo-
ber, 1979, at which time the October 1978 Term will end.
"The October 1979 Term of the Court will begin as provided by law,
on the first Monday in October."
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 78–1922. American Federation of Labor and Congress of In-
dustrial Organizations et al., petitioners, v. Alfred E. Kahn, Chair-
man of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, et al. Motion to dis-
pense with printing petition and to expedite consideration granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the District of Columbia Circuit denied. Mr. Justice Brennan,
Mr. Justice White, and Mr. Justice Marshall would grant certiorari.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Mr. Chief Justice Burger, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Jus-
tice Stewart, Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 78-610. Columbus Board of Education et al., petitioners, v.
Gary L. Penick et al. Motion to issue judgment, or in the alternative
to vacate stay, was presented to Mr. Justice White and by him referred
to the Court. It is ordered that the stay entered by Mr. Justice Rehn-
quist on August 11, 1978, is vacated. It is further ordered that the
judgment of this Court shall issue forthwith. Mr. Justice Rehnquist
took no part in the consideration or decision of these orders.
